titleStmt.title: The arraignment, tryal, conviction and condemnation of Henry Harrison, Gent. for the barbarous murther of Andrew Clenche, of Brownelowe-Street, in the parish of St. Andrew's Holborne, in the county of Middlesex, Doctor of physick at the sessions of the goal-delivery of Newgate, holden for the city of London, at Justice-Hall in the Old-Baily, on the 6th, 7th, and 9th days of April, 1692, in the fourth year of Their Majesties reign : and also the examination of the said Henry Harrison, taken the 6th day of January, 1691, before the Right Honourable Sir John Holt, Knight, Lord Chief Justice of Their Majesties Court of King's and Queen's Bench at Westminster : to which is also added, The tryal of John Cole, for the murther of the said Doctor Clenche.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: I Do Appoint William Battersby and Thomas Braddyll to Print the Å¿everal Trials of Henry HarriÅ¿on, Gent. and John Cole, for the Murther of Dr. Andrew Clenche, and alÅ¿o the Examination of the Å¿aid Henry HarriÅ¿on taken before the Lord Chief JuÅ¿tice Holt, concerning the Å¿aid Murther; together with a Preface to the Å¿aid Trials: And that no other do PreÅ¿ume to Print the Å¿ame.

THE Arraignment, Tryal, Conviction and Condemnation of Henry HarriÅ¿on, Gent. For the Barbarous MURTHER OF Andrew Clenche, OF Brownlowe-Å¿treet, in the PariÅ¿h of St. Andrew's Holborne, in the County of MiddleÅ¿ex, Doctor of PhyÅ¿ick. At the SeÅ¿Å¿ions of Goal-delivery of Newgate, holden for the City of London, at JuÅ¿tice-Hall in the Old-Baily, on the 6th, 7th, and 9th, days of April, 1692. in the Fourth Year of their MajeÅ¿ties Reign: And alÅ¿o the Examination of the Å¿aid Henry HarriÅ¿on, taken the 6th, day of January, 1691. before the Right Honourable Sir John Holt, Knight, Lord Chief JuÅ¿tice of their MajeÅ¿ties Court of King's and Queens Bench at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter. To which is alÅ¿o added, the Tryal of John Cole, for the Murther of the Å¿aid Doctor Clenche.
LONDON, Printed by Thomas Braddyll, and are to be Sold by William Battersby at Thavies-Inn-Gate, and R. Baldwin near the Oxford-Arms in Warwick-lane, MDCXCII.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: THE Murther of Doctor Andrew Clenche (from the manner of it) did very much diÅ¿turb the Thoughts of many M â¢ n. But the Evidence againÅ¿t Henry HarriÅ¿on, Gent. at his Tryal for that Murther, was Å¿o full and Å¿atisfactory to all that heard it, That it was then believed there was not any doubt left of his being one of the Actors of that Murther. But there having been Å¿ome Endeavours Å¿ince by the AccuÅ¿ation of one John Cole, and others, to make the Å¿aid Henry HarriÅ¿on appear Innocent, and to Arraign the JuÅ¿tice of the Kingdom. It is therefore thought neceÅ¿Å¿ary to publiÅ¿h both the Trials of the Å¿aid Henry HarriÅ¿on and John Cole, for the Satisfaction of all PerÅ¿ons, and in hopes alÅ¿o, that it may be a means of as happy a DiÅ¿covery of the Managers of that AccuÅ¿ation, as there was by great Providence of one of the Actors of that Å¿ecret and cruel Murther.

div.head: THE Arraignment, Tryal, Conviction and Condemnation of Henry HarriÅ¿on, Gent. FOR THE MURTHER OF Dr. Andrew Clenche.

dateline.date: Die Mercurii Sexto die Aprilis, Anno Regni Domini Gulielmi & Dominoe Marioe Regis & Reginoe, Anglioe, &c. Quarto.

div.p: THE Keeper of the PriÅ¿on of Newgate did, according to Order of the Court being then Å¿ate, bring up the Body of Henry HarriÅ¿on, Gent. to the SeÅ¿Å¿ions-HouÅ¿e in the Old-Baily, London, who being at the Bar, was Arraigned upon an Indictment of Felony and Murther, found that Day by the Grand-Jury for the City of London, in manner following:

sp.speaker: Clerk of Arraignment.
sp.p: HEnry HarriÅ¿on, hold up thy Hand

You Å¿tand Indicted by the Name of Henry HarriÅ¿on, late of London, Gent. for that you not having the fear of God before your Eyes, but being mov'd and Å¿educ'd by the InÅ¿tigation of the Devil, the Fourth Day of January, in the Third Year of the Reign of our Sovereign Lord and Lady, King William and Queen Mary, of England, &c. about Eleven of the Clock in the Night of the Å¿ame Day, with Force and Arms, &c. at London, viz. in the PariÅ¿h of St Peter Cornhill, in the Ward of LimeÅ¿treet in London
aforeÅ¿aid, being in a certain Coach with one Andrew Clenche Doctor of PhyÅ¿ick, and a certain Man yet unknown, in and upon the Å¿aid Andrew Clenche in the Peace of God, and of our Sovereign Lord and Lady the King and Queen, then and there being Violently, FeloniouÅ¿ly and of your Malice before-thought, did make an AÅ¿Å¿ault. And that you the Å¿aid Henry HarriÅ¿on, with the Help and AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the Å¿aid Man unknown, with a Pocket Handkerchief with a Coal in the Å¿ame, being put, of the value of Two Pence, about the Neck of him the Å¿aid Andrew Clenche, then and there FeloniouÅ¿ly, Voluntarily and of your Malice before-thought did put, faÅ¿ten and bind; and that you the Å¿aid Henry HarriÅ¿on with the Å¿aid Handkerchief with the Coal aforeÅ¿aid in it, by you the Å¿aid Henry HarriÅ¿on with the Help and AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the aforeÅ¿aid Man unknown about the Neck of the Å¿aid Andrew Clenche then as aforeÅ¿aid, put, faÅ¿tened and bound him the Å¿aid Andrew Clenche then and there with Force and Arms, &c. FeloniouÅ¿ly, Voluntarily and of your Malice beforethought did choak and Å¿trangle, by ReaÅ¿on of which choaking and Å¿trangling of the Å¿aid Andrew Clenche by you the Å¿aid Henry HarriÅ¿on, with the Handkerchief aforeÅ¿aid, with the Coal as aforeÅ¿aid put in it, he the Å¿aid Andrew Clenche inÅ¿tantly died: So that you the Å¿aid Henry HarriÅ¿on with the Help and AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the Å¿aid Man unknown, him the Å¿aid Andrew Clenche the Å¿aid fourth Day of January in the Year aforeÅ¿aid at the PariÅ¿h and Wa â¢ d aforeÅ¿aid in manner and form aforeÅ¿aid, FeloniouÅ¿ly, Voluntarily and of your Malice beforethought did Kill and Murther againÅ¿t the Peace of our Sovereign Lord and Lady the King and Queen now, their Crown and Dignity.
How Å¿ay you, Henry HarriÅ¿on, are you Guilty of this Felony and Murther whereof you Å¿tand Indicted, or not Guilty?

sp.speaker: Mr HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Not Guilty in Thought, Word not Deed.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: CulprieÅ¿t, How will you be Tryed?

sp.speaker: Mr HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: By God and my Country.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: God Å¿end you a good Deliverance.

div.p: Then the Å¿aid Mr HarriÅ¿on was taken away from the Bar by the Keeper of Newgate.

And afterwards the Å¿ame Day, about Eleven of the Clock in the Morning, the Å¿aid Henry HarriÅ¿on was brought to the Bar, and he deÅ¿ired the Court that he might then be Tryed, which was granted, and thoÅ¿e PerÅ¿ons who were return'd upon the Jury were called over twice, and their Appearances recorded.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: You Henry HarriÅ¿on, TheÅ¿e Men that you Å¿hall hear call'd, and perÅ¿onally do appear, are to paÅ¿s between our Sovereign Lord and Lady the King and Queen, and you upon Tryal of your Life and Death; if therefore you will challenge them, or any of them, your time is to challenge them as they come to the Book to be Sworn, and before they be Sworn.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Holt.
sp.p: Mr HarriÅ¿on, you may challenge Å¿uch of the Jury as you Å¿hall think fit before they be Sworn.

div.p:
Then the Jury was called and Å¿worn, and then were counted; and the Twelve Å¿worn were theÅ¿e whoÅ¿e Names follow:
JURORS.
John Roll
Nathaniel Houlton
Michael Pindar
James Hulbert
JoÅ¿eph Howe
Richard Chewne
John Lawford
Nicholas Wildeboare
Robert WilliamÅ¿on
William Merriden
Thomas SimpÅ¿on
Thomas Pakeman
Sworn.
Then Proclamation for Information and Evidence was made as is uÅ¿ual.

sp.speaker: Mr HarriÅ¿on,
sp.p: My Lord, I have made no Challenges, becauÅ¿e I do believe the Jury to be honeÅ¿t Men.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr.
sp.p: âHenry HarriÅ¿on, Hold up thy Hand.
Gentlemen, you that are Å¿worn, look upon the PriÅ¿oner, and hearken to his CauÅ¿e. He Å¿tands indicted by the Name of Henry HarriÅ¿on, late of London, Gent. &c.

Upon this Indictment he hath been Arraigned, and thereunto hath pleaded not Guilty; and for his Tryal hath put himÅ¿elf upon God and his Country, which Country you are. Your Charge is to enquire whether he be Guilty of this Felony and Murther wherof he Å¿tands Indicted, or not Guilty: If you find that he is Guilty, you are to enquire what Goods or Chattels, Lands or Tenements he had at the time of the Felony and Murther committed, or at any time Å¿ince. If you find him not Guilty, you are to enquire whether he Å¿led for it. If you find that he fled for it, you are to enquire of his Goods and Chattels, as if you found him Guilty. If you find him not Guilty, nor that he did fly for it, you are to Å¿ay Å¿o, and no more; and hear your Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr Darnell,
sp.p: âMy Lords, Mr HarriÅ¿on's Agents or Friends have Å¿ince the laÅ¿t SeÅ¿Å¿ions, made or conveyed away a young Man that was a Principal Evidence againÅ¿t him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That is a very ill thing, and if it be prov'd, it will no way conduce to Mr HarriÅ¿on's Advantage.

sp.speaker: Mr HarriÅ¿on,
sp.p: My Lord, I know nothing of it. But my Lord, one of my WitneÅ¿Å¿es that would have been material for me, is lately dead, Sir Edward Hungerford's Son.

sp.speaker: Mr Darnell,
sp.p:
May it pleaÅ¿e your LordÅ¿hips, and you Gentlemen that are Å¿worn, I am of Councel for the King and Queen againÅ¿t the PriÅ¿oner at the Barr, who Å¿tands Indicted for the Murther of Dr Andrew Clenche, which was as barbarous a Murther as any that hath been committed in this Age. And conÅ¿idering it was done in the Dark, I think there will be given as clear an Evidence of it againÅ¿t Mr HarriÅ¿on the PriÅ¿oner, as can be expected. And that it was upon
this occaÅ¿ion one Mrs Vanwicke a Widdow (between whom and Mr HarriÅ¿on there was a great KindneÅ¿s) prevailed with Dr Clenche, to whom Å¿he was indebted twenty Pounds, to lend her Å¿o much more as would make it up one hundred and twenty Pounds, and to take a Mortgage of a HouÅ¿e of hers in Buckingham Court near Charing-CroÅ¿s for his Security; and Mr HarriÅ¿on was preÅ¿ent with Mrs Vanwicke at the lending of the reÅ¿t of the Money, and executing of the Mortgage, as he was wont to he at the Management of her Affairs; but when the time came that it was to be repaid, the Dr could not get his Money, and Mrs Vanwicke having but an EÅ¿tare for Life in the HouÅ¿e, and having long delayed the Doctor, he brought an Ejectment for the recovering of the HouÅ¿e, upon which the PriÅ¿oner came to Dr Clenche, and abuÅ¿ed him with very Å¿currilous Language, and his PaÅ¿Å¿ion growing higher, he laid his hand upon his â¢â¢ ord, and would have drawn it, and if it had not been for one Mr JohnÅ¿on, 'twas thought he would have kill'd the Doctor at that time; Å¿o that the Doctor deÅ¿ired Mr JohnÅ¿on to take the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s upon himÅ¿elf, and to act in his own Name, he was Å¿o much afraid of him. And it will be proved further to you, that at another time the PriÅ¿oner Å¿aid, That Dr Clenche was a Rogue and a Villain, and deÅ¿erved to have his Throat cut. And Å¿ometime after this Mrs Vanwicke would have borrowed Å¿ome more Money of the Doctor, but he refuÅ¿ed to lend it her, whereupon Å¿he acquainting the PriÅ¿oner with it, he Å¿aid, leave him to me (Madam) I'll warrant you, I'll manage him, he is a Rogue, and deÅ¿erves to have his Throat cut. And afterwards about St Thomas's day laÅ¿t, the PriÅ¿oner went to Mrs WeÅ¿t the Tennant, who dwelt in the HouÅ¿e mortgaged to Dr Clenche, and deÅ¿ired of Mrs WeÅ¿t to have Å¿ome Money for Mrs Vanwicke, and Å¿aid it Å¿hould be diÅ¿counted in part of the then next ChriÅ¿tmas Rent. But the Å¿aid Mrs WeÅ¿t refuÅ¿ed to pay him any, telling him that Å¿he and her Husband were forbid by Dr Clenche and the Ground Land-Lord, to pay any more to Mrs Vanwicke, and thereupon the PriÅ¿oner expreÅ¿Å¿ed his further Malice againÅ¿t the Doctor, and Å¿aid he is a great Rogue, and a Villain, and deÅ¿erves to have his Throat cut, and will not dye in his Bed. And, Gentlemen, Å¿oon after the PriÅ¿oner began to put his malicious DeÅ¿ign againÅ¿t the Doctor in Execution, and the Method he took was firÅ¿t to change his Lodgings, for on the day before ChriÅ¿tmas Eve laÅ¿t, he took new Lodgings at one Mr Garways in Thread-Needle-Å¿treet, near the Old Exchange, attended by a Foot-boy, pretending himÅ¿elf to be a Parliament Man, and that he was juÅ¿t then come out of the Country, and lay in his Lodging there every Night, until the firÅ¿t day of January following, but lay out that Night, and the two next Nights following. And whilÅ¿t he lodged at this Mr Garways this matter hapned, which does conduce Å¿omewhat towards the diÅ¿covery of this Murther. One Evening the PriÅ¿oner being in his Chamber there, and one Mrs JackÅ¿on, the Daughter of Mrs Garway, making a Fire for him, he did take out his Handkerchief, and held it before the Fire to dry it, which Å¿he took great notice of, becauÅ¿e it was courÅ¿e and dirty, and not Å¿it for his Quality (as Å¿he thought) it being made of ordinary Indian Å¿tuff, like her Mothers Maids
Apron. And, Gentlemen, this very Handkerchief was the Å¿ame with which the Murther was committed, and this Mrs JackÅ¿on will Å¿wear it to be the Å¿ame, for it is a very remarkable one, and it will be produced to you. And we Å¿hall Å¿hew you further, that on the Third Day of January (being the Day before this Murther was committed) he cauÅ¿ed a Å¿ham Letter to be left for him at his Lodgings at this Mr Garway's, as written from a Friend of his that was Sick in the Country, earneÅ¿ly preÅ¿Å¿ing him to come quickly down to him: And we Å¿hall prove that the very Å¿ame Evening he being with Mrs Vanwick in WoodÅ¿treet-Counter, did again threaten Dr Clenche, and Å¿aid that he was a Rogue, and he would have his Blood. And upon the Fourth Day of January laÅ¿t he again changed his Lodgings, and took new ones at one Mr Jones's a Cane-Chair-maker in St Paul's Church-yard, and there he pretended himÅ¿elf to be a Country Gentleman, juÅ¿t then come out of Cumberland, and brought in a Portmanteau Trunk thither. And the Å¿ame Day he Å¿ent a Letter to Mrs Garway where he had lodged before, acquainting her that he was gone out of Town for a Week or ten Days. And, to give you farther Satisfaction, we Å¿hall prove that upon the Å¿ame Fourth Day of January in the Night of which this unfortunate Gentleman was Murther'd, the PriÅ¿oner was at one Mr Robert HumÅ¿ton's Lodgings at the Golden-Key in FleetÅ¿treet over againÅ¿t Fetter-lane End, at near Nine of the Clock at Night, and being ask'd by Mr HumÅ¿ton to Å¿tay and Sup with him, he Å¿aid he could not, for he had been about earneÅ¿t BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s that Day, which was to be done that Night, and that a Gentleman Å¿tayed for him in the Street to go with him about it, and Å¿o he went away. And Å¿oon after, about Nine of the Clock the Å¿ame Night, two Men Å¿tanding in FleetÅ¿treet at Fetterlane End, call'd for a Coach, and ask'd the Coachman if he knew Dr Clenche who dwelt in BrownlowÅ¿treet in Holborn; and the Coachman reply'd, he did know the Street, but not the Doctor, whereupon they went into the Coach, and ordered him to live to the End of BrownlowÅ¿treet, and when they came thither, one of them called to the Coachman and bad him go to Dr Clenche's and tell him, that two Gentlemen in a Coach at the End of the Street deÅ¿ired him to go with them to a Patient that was very Sick, which the Coachman did. And he found the Doctor in his Night-Gown and Slippers, and juÅ¿t a going to Bed; but he immediately dreÅ¿Å¿ed himÅ¿elf, and went to them into the Coach. And it fell out very happily for the further DiÅ¿covery of this Murther, that while this Coach Å¿tood at the End of BrownlowÅ¿treet, a Young Gentlewoman Å¿tanding at her own Door near it, and fancying that while the Coachman went on the Errand, the Gentlemen would Å¿hip out of the Coach (I think they call it Bilking) Å¿he watch'd them And a Lamp that lighted croÅ¿s Holborn over againÅ¿t BrownlowÅ¿treet End, and another about the middle of BrownlowÅ¿treet, gave Å¿uch a light into the Coach, that Å¿he plainly Å¿aw one of the Men that Å¿ate in it, and Å¿ee him look out of the Coach after the Coachman, and heard him Å¿wear at the Coachman, becauÅ¿e he made no more haÅ¿te in going to the Doctor's HouÅ¿e, and Å¿he is very certain that the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar is the Å¿ame PerÅ¿on that look'd out of the Coach, and that did
Å¿wear â¢ t the Coachman, and is more confident of it from the remarkableneÅ¿ â¢ of his Voice. For Å¿he hearing of this Murther and remembring theÅ¿e CircumÅ¿tances, Å¿he went to Newgate to Å¿ee the PriÅ¿oner, and hearing his Voice in another Room, before Å¿he Å¿aw him; Å¿he declar'd to the PerÅ¿ons that were then with her, that the Voice Å¿he then heard was the PerÅ¿ons Voice that Å¿he Å¿aw look out of the Coach, and that did Å¿wear at the Coachman; and afterwards when Å¿he came into the Room where the PriÅ¿oner was, though with Å¿everal other Men, Å¿he pointed to him as the PerÅ¿on, and Å¿he hearing him then Å¿peak again, declared to the PerÅ¿ons with her, that both by his Voice and by his Countenance Å¿he knew him to be the Å¿ame Man. And, my Lord, after thoÅ¿e Gentlemen had gotten the Doctor into the Coach, one of them called to the Coachman, and bad him make haÅ¿te and drive them to Leaden-Hall Market, and when they were come within Holbourn-Bars one of them called to the Coachman and bad him drive faÅ¿ter; whereupon the Coachman drove them very faÅ¿t through Holbourn to Leaden-Hall-Market-Gate, and when he came there, one of them bad him drive to the Pye without Aldgate (before which time, without doubt, the Murther was committed upon the Doctor, for his Hat was found next morning in Holborn near Fetter-lane End, but the driving Å¿o long about after is Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to be done leaÅ¿t the Doctor might recover) and when they were come without Aldgate, one of them ordered the Coachman to ask there for one Hunt a Chyrurgeon; which he did, and being anÅ¿wered that no Å¿uch PerÅ¿on was there, he ordered the Coachman to drive back again to Leaden-Hall, and when they came there, one of them called the Coachman and gave him Three Shillings and Six Pence, and bad him go into the Market there to one Hunt's a Poulterer, and buy them a couple of Fowls, but the Coachman could not find any Hunt a Poulterer, but however he bought a couple of Fowls for Three Shillings, and when he came with them to his Coach, the two Gentlemen were gone and the Doctor left in the Coach murther'd with a Handkerchief tied faÅ¿t about his Neck with a Coal in it (which will be proved to be the PriÅ¿oners Handkerchief.) BeÅ¿ides there was a Boy in the Street there who took notice of the Coachman's being Å¿ent of an Errand, and Å¿aw the two PerÅ¿ons come out of the Coach in great haÅ¿te, and Å¿he going towards the Coach before they went out of it, one of them did Å¿wear at him to be gone, and of him the Boy took moÅ¿t notice, and was as poÅ¿Å¿itive as any man can be to the PerÅ¿on of one that he never Å¿aw before, that the PriÅ¿oner now at the Bar was one of them, and was the PerÅ¿on that did then Å¿wear at him. But this WitneÅ¿s is Å¿pirited away and cannot be heard of, although he hath been deÅ¿cribed in the Gazettee, and diligent Å¿earch and inquiry has been made after him. But we have his Examination upon Oath before the Coroner; and we muÅ¿t Å¿ubmit to the Court how far that Å¿hall be admitted as Evidence.
Gentlemen, We will call our WitneÅ¿Å¿es, and if they prove all this matter, I believe every Man here will be Å¿atisfied that the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar is Guilty of this baÅ¿e murther.

sp.speaker: Mr Darnell.
sp.p: Pray call and Å¿wear Mr George Wigmore.

sp.speaker: Mr Darnell,
sp.p: Pray Mr Wigmore tell my Lord and the Jury what you know of any Money that was lent by Dr Clenche, and to whom.

sp.speaker: Mr George Wigmore,
sp.p: May it pleaÅ¿e your LordÅ¿hip, there was a draught of a Mortgage from Mrs Vanwicke to Dr Clenche, made by a Gentleman of Grays-Inn for the Sum of One hundred and twenty Pounds, and I IngroÅ¿s'd it; and I paid by the Doctors Order above ThreeÅ¿core Pounds of the Money, and the reÅ¿t of it was Å¿atisfied before; and upon Å¿ealing of the Mortgage for the Money, Mr HarriÅ¿on, and one Mr Rowe fell out about their Dividend of the Money, and called one another ill Names; and Mr Rowe produced a Bill of what he had done and laid out for Coach-hire and other things for Mrs Vanwicke, and Mr HarriÅ¿on and he had high words about it, and called one another Rogues; Å¿o I told them if they could not agree, I would put the Money up again, and carry it home; but Mrs Vanwicke and they did agree at laÅ¿t, and Å¿ealed the Mortgage, and I paid the Money; and Mrs Vanwicke and Mr HarriÅ¿on took out twenty Pounds of the Money, and paid it to Mr Rowe; and after Mr Rowe was gone, they deÅ¿ired me to go with them to the Young Devil Tavern, and they both uÅ¿ed hard ExpreÅ¿Å¿ions there againÅ¿t Mr Rowe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who was the Mortgage made to?

sp.speaker: Mr Wigmore,
sp.p: My Lord, it was made to Dr Clenche for one hundred and twenty Pounds.

sp.speaker: Mr HarriÅ¿on,
sp.p: Pray Sir will you tell the Jury how much Money the Gentlewoman had, and if Mr. Row had not Å¿tept between me and her, I had not been in QueÅ¿tion.

sp.speaker: Mr Wigmore,
sp.p: Mrs Vanwicke acknowledged that the Money I paid her, made up one hundred and twenty Pounds.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did you hear the PriÅ¿oner Å¿ay againÅ¿t Dr Clenche?

sp.speaker: Mr Wigmore,
sp.p: My Lord, I do Å¿ay that he was very troubleÅ¿ome to the Doctor.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were there any Reproaches caÅ¿t upon the Doctor at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr Wigmore,
sp.p: No my Lord, only upon Rowe, becauÅ¿e he was a TruÅ¿tee.

sp.speaker: Mr Darnell,
sp.p: Did you hear him Å¿ay any thing againÅ¿t the Doctor?

sp.speaker: Mr Wigmore,
sp.p: Indeed I cannot particularly Å¿ay.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He is upon his Oath, and he is Å¿enÅ¿ible and underÅ¿tands the QueÅ¿tion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wigmore.
sp.p: He did Å¿ay very ugly Words, and when I met him afterwards in the High-way, he was very huÅ¿Å¿y, and I thought he would have drawn his Sword upon me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did he Å¿ay of the Doctor?

sp.speaker: Mr Wigmore,
sp.p: I cannot Å¿ay particularly what he Å¿aid.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Stand down.

sp.speaker: Mr Darnell,
sp.p: Call Mr Thomas JohnÅ¿on

sp.speaker: Mr Darnell,
sp.p: Sir, Pray give the Court an Account what you know concerning this Matter.

sp.speaker: Mr JohnÅ¿on,
sp.p:
My Lord, I believe I Å¿hall Å¿ay nothing that Mr HarriÅ¿on will contradict, I was Attorny for Dr Clenche between him and Mrs Vanwicke, and I Å¿ued Mr Rowe that was bound with Mrs Vanwicke
in a Bond to perform Covenants for re-payment of the Money lent her by Dr Clenche upon Mortgage; and I adviÅ¿ed the Dr. and told him, don't let us trouble the Tenant, but let us take Rowe firÅ¿t; and I Å¿ued Rowe, and had him arreÅ¿ted, and after Å¿ome time, I Å¿aw that the Mortgage muÅ¿t do our buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, for Rowe could not pay the Money, whereupon I cauÅ¿ed a Declaration in Ejectment to be delivered againÅ¿t Mrs Vanwick's Tenant of the HouÅ¿e Mortgaged by her to Dr Clenche, and then Mr HarriÅ¿on came to me, and he expreÅ¿Å¿ed himÅ¿elf againÅ¿t the Dr after a Å¿trange rate, and laid his Hand upon his Sword, Å¿o my Lord I Å¿aid to him, what a Fool do you make of your Å¿elf? muÅ¿t none go to Law, but they muÅ¿t ask you leave, I Å¿uppoÅ¿e Mr HarriÅ¿on cannot deny this. Then Mr HarriÅ¿on preferred a Petition to the Lords CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners of the Great Seal for Mrs Vanwicke, and thereby Å¿uggeÅ¿ted to their LordÅ¿hips that Å¿he was wronged in the PurchaÅ¿e and in the Mortgage Money, and that twenty Pounds of it was a former debt of her Husbands; and he finding Å¿he could have no Relief before them without payment of the Mortgage Money, he grew troubleÅ¿ome; yet Å¿ays I, Mr HarriÅ¿on, What Å¿he hath done, I cannot help, but if Å¿he would pay the reÅ¿t, I told him I would abate her twenty Pounds, and the IntereÅ¿t Money alÅ¿o.

sp.speaker: Mr Darnell,
sp.p: Pray Sir, did the Dr deÅ¿ire you to act for him in your own Name, becauÅ¿e he had no mind to meet with Mrs Vanwicke and the PriÅ¿oner?

sp.speaker: Mr JohnÅ¿on,
sp.p: The Doctor did find himÅ¿elf too deeply concerned with them, and he did not care to have to do with them, whether it was that he was afraid of his Life, I cannot Å¿ay; but he Å¿aid to me, Pray Sir, go on, I will put all into your hands, and I will truÅ¿t you with all the Affair, and let them come to you, and not trouble me, own it to be your own; and I told him, I feared none of them, and the Doctor gave out that he had made over all to me, although he had not, and upon this I fear, comes this unfortunate BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s, and the Doctor's Lady muÅ¿t look after it her Å¿elf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did he Å¿ay when he had laid his Hand upon his Sword in your Study.

sp.speaker: Mr JohnÅ¿on,
sp.p: He Å¿aid the Dr. had cheated the Widdow, and he Å¿aid that he would be revenged on him, as near as my Memory will Å¿erve me, I Å¿uppoÅ¿e he will not deny it; whether he did this in a PaÅ¿Å¿ion, or to affright the Doctor or no, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was that before you offered to abate the twenty Pounds?

sp.speaker: Mr JohnÅ¿on,
sp.p: It was before I offered to abate it.

sp.speaker: Mr HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: How long was it before Dr Clenche was murthred?

sp.speaker: Mr JohnÅ¿on,
sp.p: I think it was about a Fortnight or three Weeks, or a little more.

sp.speaker: Mr HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: I never threatned the Doctor in my Life, but I Å¿aid Rowe had been a Villain and a Cheat, and he and Rowe were the Men, and I Å¿hall make it appear that the Dr never wrong'd the Widdow.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came Rowe to be intruÅ¿ted or concerned with the Money?

sp.speaker: Mr JohnÅ¿on,
sp.p: My Lord, Mr Cornelius Vandinanker, a Merchant, gave a Legacy of five hundred Pounds to the Widdow Vanwicke and her Children, and Mr Rowe was a TruÅ¿tee on the PurchaÅ¿e, and had by that the management of the Affair.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call Mr. George Howard.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Mr. Howard, Give the Court an Account of what you know concerning the PriÅ¿oner's threatning Dr. Clenche.

sp.speaker: Mr. Howard.
sp.p: My Lord, I was at Joe's Coffee-houÅ¿e near Warwick-HouÅ¿e in Holborn, Å¿ome conÅ¿iderable time before Dr. Clenche was Murdred, where Mr. HarriÅ¿on uÅ¿ed Å¿everal very virulent ExpreÅ¿Å¿ions againÅ¿t Dr. Clenche; amongÅ¿t others, one was, That he was a Rogue and a RaÅ¿cal, and deÅ¿erved to have his Throat Cut. Mrs. Vanwick was then in Company, and they both Å¿aid, That they then came from Dr. Clenche's.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: You are Å¿ure he Å¿aid that Dr. Clenche deÅ¿erved to have his Throat Cut.

sp.speaker: Mr. Howard.
sp.p: Yes: He Å¿aid, That Dr. Clenche deÅ¿erved to have his Throat Cut.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Who was I talking to?

sp.speaker: Mr. Howard
sp.p: You were talking to Mrs. Mary Sheriff.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call Mrs. Mary Sheriff.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sheriff.
sp.p: My Lord, Mrs. Vanwick came to my HouÅ¿e with Mr. HarriÅ¿on, and deÅ¿ired me to go with her to Dr. Clenche his HouÅ¿e; and when we came there, Å¿he deÅ¿ired him to let her have Twenty Pounds more; and he Å¿aid, No. If his HouÅ¿e were full of Money, he would not lend her any more, Å¿o long as Å¿he kept Mr. HarriÅ¿on Company, for he would Å¿pend it; and he adviÅ¿ed her to be a Gentleman's HouÅ¿e-keeper, and he would help her to a Place; and told her withal, That Å¿he owed him, One Hundred and Twenty Pounds, for which he would take One Hundred Pounds; and we left Mr. HarriÅ¿on behind us at my HouÅ¿e, and did not take him with us, becauÅ¿e we were afraid he might anger the Doctor, and fall out with him; Å¿o when we came back, Mr. HarriÅ¿on asked Mrs. Vanwick, what Dr. Clenche Å¿aid; Why, Å¿ays Å¿he, he Å¿aith, That he will not lend me any more Money while I keep you Company, for you will Å¿pend it, and that I muÅ¿t go to Service. To Service! Å¿aid Mr. HarriÅ¿on. God damne him, have a PerÅ¿on of your Quality go to Service! he deÅ¿erves to have his Throat Cut; let me alone; I'll manage him as never any Man was managed, and Å¿o away they went together.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Did not you Å¿ay, that as you hop'd to be Å¿av'd, that I was Innocent of the Thing?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: She does not AccuÅ¿e you of doing the Fact, but gives an Account of Å¿ome ExpreÅ¿Å¿ions that paÅ¿Å¿ed from you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sheriff.
sp.p: You were always talking againÅ¿t Dr Clenche, and you Å¿aid, God damne him, he was an Old Rogue, and that Mrs. Vanwick was almoÅ¿t Starved to Death.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Rowe, Rowe, I meant, my Lord.

div.p: (The PriÅ¿oner being then in a PaÅ¿Å¿ion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. HarriÅ¿on, do not fall into a PaÅ¿Å¿ion, it may be more to your Advantage, in the making your Defence, if you keep your Temper.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: WitneÅ¿s, What were the Words that he Å¿aid againÅ¿t Doctor Clenche?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sheriff.
sp.p: Why, he Å¿peaking of Doctor Clenche, Å¿aid to Mrs. Vanwick, God damne him, would he have a PerÅ¿on of your Quality go to Service! he deÅ¿erves to have his Throat Cut; well, Madam, Å¿ays he, be contented I'll manage him as never any Man was managed.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: What had you for your Swearing?
Coroner for the King and Queen. WitneÅ¿s, he asketh you, if you had any thing for your Swearing againÅ¿t him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sheriff.
sp.p: No, I had nothing, neither have I need of any thing; I had not Å¿o much as my Coach-hire.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call Mrs. Elizabeth WeÅ¿t.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: MiÅ¿treÅ¿s, give an Account to the Court, what you know about the PriÅ¿oner's coming to demand Rent of you, and what paÅ¿Å¿ed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. WeÅ¿t.
sp.p:
May it pleaÅ¿e your LordÅ¿hip, this Gentleman, the PriÅ¿oner, came to me two or three Days before St. Thomas his Day laÅ¿t, and deÅ¿ired me to give him Å¿ome Rent for Mrs. Vanwick, and I told him, I had no Power to Pay him, becauÅ¿e I was warned by Dr. Clenche, to Pay no more; Å¿ays he to me again, Dr. Clenche, and Rowe, are great Rogues and great Villains. Sir, Å¿ays I to him again, I believe that the Doctor is a very honeÅ¿t Man: No, Å¿ays Mr. HarriÅ¿on, he is a great Villain, and he will never Die in his Bed; which of them he meant, Mr. Rowe or Dr. Clenche, I cannot tell. And Mrs. Vanwick, and Mr. HarriÅ¿on, a little time before that, preÅ¿Å¿ed me, to let
them have Å¿ome Shop Goods in part of her Rent, to grow due, and Å¿he made great Complaint, that her Children were ready to Starve, and I then told them, that Mr. JohnÅ¿on had fore-warned me to pay any more Rent to Mrs. Vanwick, and if I did, I Å¿hould pay it again; and therefore I would not pay any more Rent to her, or deliver her any Goods, until Å¿he had agreed with Mr. JohnÅ¿on, and then Mr. HarriÅ¿on Å¿aid, that Mr. JohnÅ¿on was a great Villain, and a great Rogue, and that they had all Combined together to Cheat the Widow. And Mr. JohnÅ¿on being at my HouÅ¿e, Mrs. Vanwick fell upon him in a great Rage, and Å¿aid, Å¿he would Tear his Throat out, and laid hold on him, and Mr. JohnÅ¿on got from her, and went away in great haÅ¿te. And the laÅ¿t time I Å¿aw Dr. Clenche, I preÅ¿Å¿ed very hard upon him, to let Mrs. Vanwick have more Money; and the Doctor Å¿aid, that Å¿he would never do any good with it, for Å¿he Å¿pent it all upon Mr. HarriÅ¿on; and I wiÅ¿hed him to let her have Twenty Pounds more, and he Å¿aid, that he adviÅ¿ed her to go to Service, and that he had wiÅ¿hed her to a Service of Twenty Pounds a Year, and Å¿he abuÅ¿ed him for it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Cloathes had the PriÅ¿oner on?

sp.speaker: Mrs. WeÅ¿t.
sp.p: My Lord, he had an Old Thread-hare black Cloth Suit of Cloaths on, which looked very Å¿habby.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: What Religion are you of, MiÅ¿treÅ¿s?

sp.speaker: Mrs. WeÅ¿t.
sp.p: I was born and bred up a ProteÅ¿tant.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: I believe you are a PapiÅ¿t, and will Swear any thing, you keep Roman Catholicks in your HouÅ¿e, they have Murdred Dr. Clenche, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did Mr. HarriÅ¿on ever Lodge in your HouÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Mrs. WeÅ¿t.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I have none but PerÅ¿ons of Quality Lodge in my HouÅ¿e, and they belong to the preÅ¿ent Government.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call Anne WatÅ¿on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Pray, tell my Lord and the Jury, what you know of Mr. HarriÅ¿on's taking of Lodgings at Mr. Garway's HouÅ¿e, and when it was.

sp.speaker: Anne WatÅ¿on.
sp.p: He came about Six a Clock at Night, the Day before ChriÅ¿tmas-Eve laÅ¿t, to my MaÅ¿ter's, Mr. Garway's HouÅ¿e, and told us, that he was newly come out of the Country; and Lodged there that Night, and Å¿o he did until, and upon the laÅ¿t Night of December; and on the firÅ¿t Day of January, he went out, and Å¿taid out that Night; and on the Sunday, the third of January laÅ¿t, at Night, he came again with a PerÅ¿on with him, and fetch'd away his Portmanteau-Trunk and things, and paid for his Lodging; and in his abÅ¿ence, there was a Letter left for him, which I gave him, and he Å¿aid, it came out of the Country, and that he had a Friend Å¿ick in the Country, and did intend to go down to Å¿ee him, being one from whom he expected a Legacy, and he left that Letter on the Kitchin Window, and on the Monday after, being the fourth Day of January laÅ¿t, he Å¿ent a Letter, Å¿ignifying he was gone out of Town.

div.p: (Then the Letter was produced, Marked with the Penny-PoÅ¿t Mark.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Who knows Mr. HarriÅ¿on's Hand? Mr. JohnÅ¿on, take that Letter and look upon it, and tell the Court if you think it to be Mr. HarriÅ¿on's Hand.

div.p: (Mr. JohnÅ¿on takes the Letter and looks upon it.

sp.speaker: Mr. JohnÅ¿on,
sp.p: My Lord, I believe it to be Mr. HarriÅ¿on's Hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: My Lord, I deÅ¿ire that the Letter may be read.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Clerk of the Peace, read the Letter; and the SubÅ¿cription firÅ¿t.

body.head: To Mrs. Garraway, at the Hand and Apple in Thread-Needle-Street, near the Royal-Exchange, PreÅ¿ent.
body.p:
I Am Å¿orry it Å¿hould be Å¿uch an inconveniency to you, as it is. I have left with your Maid, Three Half Crowns, and if it is not enough, I will give
you more. I am gone out of Town, for a Week or Ten Days, and as Å¿oon as I come again, I will wait on you, which is all till I Å¿ee you, from

closer.signed: Your Friend, and Servant, H. HarriÅ¿on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call Mr. Henry Garway and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Mrs. Garway, take that Letter, and look upon it, and tell the Court, when you received it.

div.p: (Then She takes the Letter which was produced and read as before, and looked upon it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Garway.
sp.p: My Lord, I received this Letter on Monday the 4th. Day of January laÅ¿t.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: WatÅ¿on, When did he leave the Lodgings, Å¿ay you?

sp.speaker: Anne WatÅ¿on.
sp.p: He went away the firÅ¿t of January laÅ¿t, about Nine a Clock in the Morning, and returned not that Night, but on the Å¿econd of January laÅ¿t, he was at my MiÅ¿treÅ¿s's Shop again (as my MiÅ¿treÅ¿s told me) and he came about five a Clock on the next Sunday Night (being the third of January laÅ¿t) with a PerÅ¿on with him, to my MaÅ¿ter's HouÅ¿e, and fetch'd away his Portmanteau-Trunk and Things, and left Three Half Crowns with me for his Lodgings, which I gave to my MiÅ¿treÅ¿s.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call Mrs. Catharine Jackson.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Pray, tell, my Lord and the Jury, what you know concerning Mr. HarriÅ¿on's coming to Lodge at Mr. Garway's, and when he went away, and what you know of any Handkerchief he had.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jackson.
sp.p: He came on the Day before ChriÅ¿tmas-Eve, to Lodge at my Father's, Mr. Garway's HouÅ¿e, and Lodged there Å¿everal Nights, and went away the third of January at Night, with his Things, but was abÅ¿ent Å¿ome Nights between his coming and going away, and whileÅ¿t he Lodged there, I obÅ¿erved a Handkerchief in his Hand, as I was making a Fire for him in his Chamber, and the more, becauÅ¿e he had Å¿aid, he was a Parliament-Man, and I thought it more like a Sea-Man's Handkerchief, than a Parliament-Man's, and our Maid had an Apron of the Å¿ame kind of Stuff.

div.p: (Then the Handkerchief was produced in Court, by the Coroner, and the Coal in it, wherewith Dr. Clenche was Strangled.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Mrs. Jackson, I deÅ¿ire that you would look upon that Handkerchief, and tell the Court what you know of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jackson.
sp.p: This is the Handkerchief that I Å¿aw Mr. HarriÅ¿on hold to the Fire, when I was making of it in his Chamber, or very like that Handkerchief, for I obÅ¿erved it to be very like my Mother's Maid's Apron.

div.p: (Then a piece of the Maid's Apron was produced, and they being compared, were very like.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Did you hear me Å¿ay, I was a Parliament Man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jackson.
sp.p: Yes, I heard you Å¿ay Å¿o.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Perhaps, you might hear my Boy Å¿ay Å¿o.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jackson.
sp.p: Your Foot-boy Å¿aid, you were a Parliament Man: And you Å¿aid Å¿o your Å¿elf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call Mr. Garway again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Where is the Letter you received from Mr. HarriÅ¿on, Å¿ince he was a PriÅ¿oner.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you Å¿ay, about a Letter that came to your HouÅ¿e from the PriÅ¿oner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Garway.
sp.p: My Lord, I had this Letter from him laÅ¿t Saturday, directed to my Wife, and I believe it to be his Hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: My Lord, I deÅ¿ire that the Letter may be read.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Read the Letter, Mr. Tanner.

body.head: To Mrs. Garraway, at the Hand and Apple in Thread-Needle-Street, behind the Royal Exchange, PreÅ¿ent.
body.p: I Was informed YeÅ¿terday, that you are to Appear againÅ¿t me, at next SeÅ¿Å¿ions. I am Å¿ure, you never heard me mention Dr. Clenche, in all your life; and if you do, it will look like Malice. My Lord Chief JuÅ¿tice is Å¿enÅ¿ible of the Wrong done me. This is all from

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. HarriÅ¿on, Did I ever tell you, That I was Å¿enÅ¿ible of it?

div.p: To which he made no Reply.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call Mr. John Cartwright.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: I would have you Declare, what you heard Mr. HarriÅ¿on Å¿ay, concerning Dr. Clenche.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cartwright.
sp.p: My Lord, Upon the Third of January laÅ¿t, Mr. HarriÅ¿on came to WoodÅ¿treet Compter; it was on a Sunday in the Evening, about Five or Six a Clock, I was Å¿tanding in the Gate, and I let him in. AÅ¿Å¿oon as he came in, he asked, how poor Mrs. Vanwick did; Å¿ays he, Å¿he hath been wronged of Five Hundred Pounds within this 12 Months: Then I let him into the Court, and he went into her Chamber; and about half an Hour after, I was Å¿ent by my MaÅ¿ter, to require Å¿ome Chamber-Rent of Mrs. Vanwick, and I heard Mr. HarriÅ¿on and Å¿he at high Words, and in a great PaÅ¿Å¿ion, and I heard Mr. HarriÅ¿on Swear, God damn his Blood, he would be reveng'd of that Rogue, and named Clenche or Winch, I cannot tell which, and he would have his Blood, e're it were long.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Where were you?

sp.speaker: J. Cartwright.
sp.p: My Lord, I was at the Chamber-door, and there was no Body on that Å¿ide of the HouÅ¿e, but Mr. HarriÅ¿on, Mrs. Vanwick, and my Å¿elf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call, Mrs. Mary Jones.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, I will call one to prove, where he took a new Lodging, the very Day the Murther was done.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Cartwright, Was that in Mrs. Vanwick's Chamber that you heard him Swear Å¿o?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cartwright.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, in her Chamber, and none was with her, but he only.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: You, the laÅ¿t WitneÅ¿s Mrs. Jones, When did Mr. HarriÅ¿on come to Lodge at your HouÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jones.
sp.p: He came on a Monday.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: What Day of the Month was it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jones.
sp.p: I can't tell what Day of the Month, for I did not Å¿et it down.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Was it the Monday before he was taken?

sp.speaker: Mrs Jones.
sp.p: Yes, it was the Monday before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Whence did he pretend to come?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jones.
sp.p: He Å¿aid, that he was come out of the Country, and had formerly Lodged in Fleet-Å¿treet, and that where he had Lodged formerly, they had left off HouÅ¿e-keeping, and were gone into the Country.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where is your HouÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jones.
sp.p: In Paul's Church-Yard, at the Sign of the Golden Ball.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call James HowÅ¿eman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Do you tell what you know, about Mr. HarriÅ¿on's being at Mr. Jones HouÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: James HowÅ¿eman.
sp.p: My Lord, he came in about Eight a Clock at Night, and brought a Porter with him, and a Portmanteau Trunk; and after that, the Porter went out a little before him, and then he followed him, and went out after.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Did you hear him Å¿ay, from whence he came?

sp.speaker: James HowÅ¿eman.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call Anne Evans.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Then, Call Mr. Robert HumÅ¿ton.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Mr. HumÅ¿ton, I deÅ¿ire you will give the Court an Account, of Mr. HarriÅ¿on's being at your HouÅ¿e, that Night Dr. Clenche was Murdered.

sp.speaker: Mr. HumÅ¿ton.
sp.p: My Lord, I met Mr. HarriÅ¿on on Monday the 4th of January laÅ¿t, and he told me, he was going to the Compter, to a Gentlewoman that was much oppreÅ¿Å¿ed, and that he wanted Money to get her ReleaÅ¿ed; upon which, I gave him Å¿ome Money, and after Å¿ome DiÅ¿courÅ¿e, I deÅ¿ired him to bring home my Gown, that I formerly lent him, and Å¿eemed angry with him, for that he had Å¿everal times promiÅ¿ed me to bring it home, but had failed therein; and thereupon he promiÅ¿ed, that I Å¿hould have it that Night: And that Evening about Nine of the Clock, he came to my Lodgings, and brought home my Gown, and when he came, I asked him, if he had gotten Mrs. Vanwick ReleaÅ¿ed: And Mr. HarriÅ¿on anÅ¿wered, No. Upon which, I blamed him for neglecting an old Friend, and Mr. HarriÅ¿on excuÅ¿ed it; telling me, that he had met with Å¿ome PerÅ¿oms upon earneÅ¿t BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s which prevented him. And then I asked Mr. HarriÅ¿on to Å¿tay and Sup with me, but he refuÅ¿ed it, Å¿aying, that he had been about extraordinary BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s that Day, which muÅ¿t be done that Night, and that a Gentleman Å¿tayed in the Street for him, and they two were going to do it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where do you live? And how long Å¿tayed he at your HouÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Mr. HumÅ¿ton.
sp.p: I Lodged then at the Golden Key in Fleet-Å¿treet over againÅ¿t Fetter-Lane End: He came to my Lodgings about Nine of the Clock at Night, and Å¿tayed there but a little time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What manner of Cloaths had he on.

sp.speaker: Mr. HumÅ¿ton.
sp.p: My Lord, he had a Cloak on, but I cannot tell what Cloaths he had under it, he brought my Gown up under his Cloak.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Swear EÅ¿ther King.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Do you know what time Mr. HarriÅ¿on was at Mr. HumÅ¿ton's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: EÅ¿ther King.
sp.p: It was on Monday the Fourth day of January laÅ¿t, about Nine of the Clock at Night, as near as I can gueÅ¿s, the Shop was Å¿hut up, and I let him out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Where was it?

sp.speaker: EÅ¿ther King.
sp.p: At the Golden Key in Fleet-Å¿treet over againÅ¿t Fetter-Lane End.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: What Cloaths had he on?

sp.speaker: EÅ¿ther King.
sp.p: I cannot tell well, but he had a Cloak on, I do not know, what Cloaths he had on beÅ¿ides.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Was it Eight or Nine a Clock.

sp.speaker: EÅ¿ther King.
sp.p: It was near Nine, as near as I can gueÅ¿s.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Swear John Sikes the Coachman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Give an Account to the Court, what you know about carrying two Men in your Coach, and how you found Dr. Clenche murdered.

sp.speaker: John Sikes, Coachman.
sp.p:
My Lord, on the 4th. of January laÅ¿t, being Monday, I was at the Play-houÅ¿e, and there I took up a Man and a Woman, and carried them into the
City; Å¿o I brought the Gentleman back again, to the Green Dragon Tavern in Fleet-Å¿treet; and then, he Å¿aid, he would pay me by the hour; he Å¿aid, that it was but much about Nine a Clock. Then I left him, and was driving up the Street towards the Temple, and two Men Å¿tood in Fleet-Å¿treet about Fetter-Lane End, and they asked me, if I knew Dr. Clenche, who Dwelt in Brownelowe-Å¿treet in Holbourn: I told them, that I did not know Dr. Clenche, but I knew the Street. So they went into my Coach, and one of them bad me Drive thither, and I did, and Å¿topt at the Streets End; becauÅ¿e the Gate at the other End was Å¿hut, Å¿o that I could not turn my Coach: And one of them, bad me go and tell the Dr. That there were two Gentlemen in a Coach at the Streets End, that would deÅ¿ire him, to go with them, to Å¿ee one that was not Well. The Doctor asked me, if I could tell, Who they were? Or, who it was, that he was to go to? I told him, that I could not tell The Doctor was in his Night-Gown and Slippers, and he DreÅ¿Å¿ed himÅ¿elf: And when he came to the Coach, one of them removed from his Place, and gave him the hinder-part of the Coach; and told him, That they had a Friend, that was not Well: And one of them, bad me Drive to Leaden-Hall-Market; and when I came about Holborn-Bars, one of them called to me, and asked me, Why I drove Å¿o Å¿lowly? And bad me drive faÅ¿ter; Å¿o I Drove faÅ¿t, and came to Leaden-hall. And then one of them, bad me drive to the Pye Tavern without Aldgate, and there Ordered me to Å¿top. And when I had Å¿topped there, one of them called to me, and told me, that I need not Å¿tir out of my Coach-Box; but call to the Boy at the Tavern, and ask for one Hunt a Chyrurgeon, which I did do: And when the Boy came to me again, he Å¿aid, there was no Å¿uch Man. Then one of them bad me Drive back again to Leaden-hall; and in the time I Å¿tayed there, and turned my Coach, Aldgate was Å¿hut; and when I came to the Gate, one of them gave Six Pence to the Watch, and the Gate was opened, and I drove to Leaden-hall Gate. And when I came there, I Å¿topped again, and one of them gave me Half a Crown, and bad me go and buy a Fowl of one Hunt a Poulterer; but after I had gone a little way from the Coach, he called me again, and Å¿aid, Here Coachman, you had as good take an other Shilling, and buy a Couple: So I went, and bought a couple of Fowls, but I could find no Å¿uch Poulterer as Hunt, Å¿o I bought them of another, and I gave three Shillings for them. And when I came back to the Coach Å¿ide, I found Dr. Clenche, (as I thought) Å¿itting againÅ¿t the Fore-Å¿eat, with his Head againÅ¿t the CuÅ¿hion: I pull'd him, and cried, MaÅ¿ter, MaÅ¿ter, for I thought he had been in Drink, but I could not get one word from him; and then I went to the Watch, who were near; and when they came, we found him Strangled with a Handcherchief about his Neck, and a Coal in it placed, juÅ¿t upon his Wind-Pipe, but the other two Men were gone.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Had one of the two Men a Cloak on?

sp.speaker: J. Sikes.
sp.p: I cannot remember that.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What kind of Habit had he? Had he black Cloaths on?

sp.speaker: J. Sikes.
sp.p: My Lord, I cannot tell juÅ¿tly, what Cloaths he had.

sp.speaker: L. J. C.
sp.p: You have heard him Å¿peak. What Å¿aid he?

sp.speaker: J. Sikes.
sp.p: My Lord, he never Å¿poke to me; it was the other Man.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: What kind of Man was the other? Was he leÅ¿s than I, or taller?

sp.speaker: J. Sikes.
sp.p: He was taller than you, with his own Hair.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Can you be poÅ¿itive, that the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, is one of thoÅ¿e two PerÅ¿ons.

sp.speaker: J. Sikes.
sp.p: My Lord, one of thoÅ¿e two PerÅ¿ons, had a Perriwig on, of a Light coloured Hair: And I do verily believe, that the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, is the Å¿ame PerÅ¿on; I cannot be poÅ¿itive, he is one of them, but as near as I can judge of a Man, whom I have Å¿een but once, he is one of them.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: My Lord, I deÅ¿ire your LordÅ¿hip to obÅ¿erve the time, that he took the two Men up, and what time it was that they ran out of the Coach.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Coachman, what time was it, that they left your Coach?

sp.speaker: J. Sikes.
sp.p: About half an hour paÅ¿t Ten, and it was about a quarter of an hour paÅ¿t Nine, when I took them up.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Pray let's ask the Coachman one thing more. Coachman, Look upon that Handcherchief, do you know it, and where did you Å¿ee it?

div.p: The Handkerchief was produced by the Coroner.

sp.speaker: J. Sikes.
sp.p: I do believe that it is the Å¿ame Handkerchief, that was about Dr. Clenche's Neck, when he was found Murdered.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Call the Coachman again. Harke you, In what PoÅ¿ture did you find Dr. Clenche, when you came back to your Coach?

sp.speaker: J. Sikes.
sp.p: My Lord, he was Å¿at in the Bottom of the Coach, leaning on one Å¿ide, with his head againÅ¿t the CuÅ¿hion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was a Handkerchief then about his Neck.

sp.speaker: J. Sikes.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I untied this Handkerchief, and this is the Å¿ame; and here is the Coal that was lapt in itâª It was lapt in the middle of it, and it laid juÅ¿t againÅ¿t the Doctor's Wind-Pipe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call Mr. Rebone and Mr. Marriot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Mr. Rebone, tell what you know, concerning the Handkerchief, and how you found the Doctor.

div.p: He takes the Handkerchief, and looks on't.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rebone.
sp.p: This Handkerchief, was about the Doctor's Neck, and the Coal in it, and it lay juÅ¿t upon his Wind-pipe, when I Å¿aw him Dead in the Coach. The Coachman came to Mr. Marriot's HouÅ¿e, and ask'd for a ConÅ¿table, and we went to the Coach Å¿ide, and there we found him laying along; and we took him, and carried him to the BullâInn, and there he was let Blood on the Arms, and the Chyrurgeon took about half a Spoonful of Blood out of his Right Arm; and he was let Blood on the other Arm, but that, did but juÅ¿t trickle down, and we could not get him to life again; and we found a Silver Ink-horn in his Pocket, and that, and the reÅ¿t of his things, were Å¿ecured. That is all I can Å¿ay to the Matter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call Mrs. Elianor AÅ¿hbolt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Mrs. Pray tell my Lord, and the Court, what you know of any PerÅ¿ons you Å¿aw in a Coach at Browne-lowe-Å¿treet End, that Night Dr. Clenche was Murdered.

sp.speaker: Mrs. AÅ¿hbolt.
sp.p: May it pleaÅ¿e your LordÅ¿hip, I went out of an Errand for one Madam Anwell, a Gentlewoman, who Lodges at my Mothers houÅ¿e; and coming home again, I Å¿aw a Coach Å¿top at Brownelowe-Å¿treet End, between Nine and Ten a Clock at Night, and the Coachman went to the Å¿ide of the Coach: And one in the Coach, bad him go to Dr. Clenche's, and tell him, That there were two Gentlemen Å¿tayed for him in a Coach; and as he went up the Street, he went Å¿lowly, and looked back two or three times: Whereupon, one of the PerÅ¿ons leaned out of the Coach, and did Swear at the Coachman to make haÅ¿t, and I went round the Coach, and could diÅ¿cern Mr. HarriÅ¿on's face; and I Å¿tayed, and Å¿aw Dr. Clenche go into the Coach, and one of them gave his Place to the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Why were you Å¿o curious, MiÅ¿treÅ¿s, and what did you obÅ¿erve further?

sp.speaker: Mrs. AÅ¿hbolt.
sp.p: BecauÅ¿e I thought they might give the Coach-man a Å¿lip. I well obÅ¿erved Mr. HarriÅ¿on, but do not know the other Man; there were two Lamps burning; one in Brownlowe-Street, and the other in Holborn, over-againÅ¿t the End of Brownlowe-Street; and they lighted quite through the Coach, and the Men pulled themÅ¿elves backwards, when they Å¿aw me look on them; it was that Night that the Doctor was Murdered. I went to Newgate afterwards, Madam Clenche, deÅ¿ired me to go and Å¿ee Mr. HarriÅ¿on; and when I came to Newgate, it Å¿eems, he was writing Letters, Å¿o I Å¿taid before I went into the Room; and there were two Men with me, and Mr. HarriÅ¿on was talking very loud, Å¿aid they to me, Who is that Å¿peaks now? Why, Å¿ays I, it is one of the PerÅ¿ons that was in the Coach when Dr. Clenche was Murdered.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who are thoÅ¿e two Men that were with you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. AÅ¿hbolt.
sp.p: One of them, was one Mr. Jones, a Coach-maker in Holborn, and the other, was Madam Clenche's Coach-man.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you know the PriÅ¿oner, when you Å¿aw him in Newgate, to be one of them that were in the Coach?

sp.speaker: Mrs. AÅ¿hbolt.
sp.p: Yes, I did, I knew him to be the Å¿ame Man, as Å¿oon as I Å¿aw him, and he changed Countenance as Å¿oon as he Å¿aw me.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: My Lord, this Woman is certainly hired by the Villains that are againÅ¿t me. Pray, ask her, my Lord, Why Å¿he did not make a DiÅ¿covery Å¿ooner.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: MiÅ¿treÅ¿s, What Å¿ay you to that?

sp.speaker: Mrs. AÅ¿hbolt.
sp.p: I acquainted Madam Anwell, what I had Å¿een and obÅ¿erved, and Å¿he told Madam Clenche, after laÅ¿t SeÅ¿Å¿ions, and then Å¿he deÅ¿ired me to go to Newgate, to Å¿ee Mr. HarriÅ¿on, and I went accordingly; and I would have told it to Madam Clenche Å¿ooner, but my Mother was loath I Å¿hould be concerned about Å¿uch a thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: My Lord, we have Å¿ome WitneÅ¿Å¿es who can give your LordÅ¿hip an Account, that one of our WitneÅ¿Å¿es whom I mentioned to your LordÅ¿hip before, is Å¿pirited, or withdrawn from us, by a Gentleman that Å¿aid, he came to him from the PriÅ¿oner, and deÅ¿ired him to be kind to the PriÅ¿oner, which WitneÅ¿s is Å¿ince abÅ¿ent, and not to be found; his Name was Andrew BowÅ¿ell, a Youth, and an Apprentice to one Mr. Tims, a Shooe-maker.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You muÅ¿t prove upon him, that he made him keep away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call Barnabas Smith.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Give my Lord, and the Court an Account, what you know of this matter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: My Lord, this Andrew BowÅ¿ell, which the Councel for the King, Å¿peaks of, was Å¿ent to Leaden-Hall-Street, of an Errand, to the Bull-head Ale-houÅ¿e there, and as he was going along, a Gentleman met him, and asked him, if he was not an Evidence againÅ¿t Mr. HarriÅ¿on, and being told by the Boy that he was, he deÅ¿ired him to be kind to him, and pull'd out a piece of Money, and offered it him, deÅ¿iring him to be kind to Mr. HarriÅ¿on, upon which, the Youth replied, That he owed him nothing, and nothing he would take; then the Gentleman told him, That he would come again another time, and Å¿end for him near to his MaÅ¿ter's; Å¿o the Boy Å¿aid, and told me: And Å¿aid further, That if he could have gotten him to have gone to the Bull-head Ale-houÅ¿e, he would have Å¿eized him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: What is become of the Boy?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Truly, we do not know, what is become of him, we never heard of him Å¿ince the Sixth Day of March laÅ¿t.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call his MaÅ¿ter, Mr. Richard Tims.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Tell my Lord, and the Court, what you know of this matter, and what is become of your Apprentice, Andrew BowÅ¿ell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tims.
sp.p: My Lord, he went away from me on the Sixth Day of March laÅ¿t, he was enticed away by three Souldiers, that Night, and on the Morrow Morning, one of them came and demanded his Coats, Shirts and Neckcloths; Å¿ays I to him, Who Å¿ent you, and who is your Captain? and he anÅ¿wered, why, Captain Harris; Å¿o he huÅ¿Å¿'d and Å¿aid, That if I would not give him the Cloathes, he would Å¿end his Officer; and then I told the Souldier, I would have him before a JuÅ¿tice of Peace; Å¿o he went away, and never came to me again; and I could never hear of my Apprentice Å¿ince, tho' I have made great Inquiry after him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did your Servant tell you of any Money that had been offered him by the before-mentioned Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mr. Tims.
sp.p: No, my Lord; he did not tell me, but he told Mr. Smith, the WitneÅ¿s that was laÅ¿t Examined, as he told me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: My Lord, I deÅ¿ire that Andrew BowÅ¿ell's Examination taken before Mr. John Brown, the Coroner of London, upon Oath, may be read.

div.p: Which being proved by the Coroner, were directed to be read.

sp.p: Andrew BowÅ¿ell, Servant to Richard Tims Shoomaker, Sworn and Examined touching the Death of Andrew Clench Doctor in PhyÅ¿ick, deceaÅ¿ed: Å¿aith, that he, this Informant, being Å¿ent to Mr. Parker's at the Bull-Head Ale-houÅ¿e in Leaden-Hall-Street, on Monday laÅ¿t was Seven night, being the fourth of this inÅ¿tant January, between the hours of Ten and Eleven of the Clock in the Evening, Å¿aw a Coach Å¿tanding againÅ¿t Leaden-Hall-Market, and heard Å¿ome PerÅ¿on that was in the Coach Å¿ay, make haÅ¿te. And this Informant Å¿ays, that according to the beÅ¿t of his remembrance that he heard him talk of a Poulterers; and this Informant Å¿ays, that Å¿oon after the Coachman was gone into the Market, this Informant Å¿aw two PerÅ¿ons go out of the Coach, one whereof had, as this Informant believes, a black Coat on; and that this Informant Å¿aw the Å¿ame PerÅ¿on as Å¿oon as he came out of the Coach fling a Cloak over him, and then both the PerÅ¿ons went through the Market on the weÅ¿t part: And this Informant Å¿aith, that this Informant going to look into the Coach, the PerÅ¿on that had the Cloak on him, cry'd Dam him; and this Informant Å¿aith, that he, this Informant, thereupon going away, went to Mr. Parker's, and told them that two PerÅ¿ons had cheated a Coachman, or to that effect.

Andrew BowÅ¿ell being further Examined the 23th day of January, 1691. touching the Death of Andrew Clench, Å¿aith, that he hath Å¿een Henry HarriÅ¿on, now PriÅ¿oner in Their MajeÅ¿ties Goal of Newgate, and believes he was one of the PerÅ¿ons that came out of the Coach at Leaden-hall, a little after ten of the Clock at Night, on Monday the 4th of this InÅ¿tant January; and believes he knows him by his Voice. And Å¿oon after, this Informant underÅ¿tood that the Å¿aid Andrew Clench was murther'd in a Coach, being the fame Coach which the Å¿aid HarriÅ¿on, and another PerÅ¿on unkown a little before went out of.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. HarriÅ¿on, what have you to Å¿ay againÅ¿t that which hath been proved againÅ¿t you, what defence can you make?

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on,
sp.p: My Lord, I did attend Dr. Clench about a Mortgage that was made him by Mrs. Vanwick and Dr. Clench did pay one Hundred Pounds, but this Gentlewoman would pay or allow Rowe but Fifteen Pounds, and we did not know how to get the Money from Rowe, Å¿o we Petition'd the Lords CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners about it, which was above Six Months before Doctor Clench was Murther'd; and Mr. Fairbeard wonder'd that I would put Doctor Clenche's Name into a Petition with Å¿uch a Rogue as Rowe; and I do poÅ¿itively Å¿ay, that I had not Å¿een Dr. Clench in a Month before, and if Doctor Clench had died in his Bed it had been the Å¿ame thing to me; and, my Lord, Mr. JohnÅ¿on and I had never any angry words between us; and I have the Report in Chancery which I had from Sir John Hoskins, which I will read, if your LordÅ¿hip pleaÅ¿es.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Let's Å¿ee it.

div.p: Which was handed to the Lord Chief JuÅ¿tice Sitting upon the Bench.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: My Lord, that is the Original, which if your LordÅ¿hip pleaÅ¿es to remember, I had Rowe before you twice about it, and it is Rowe that hath been the Rogue, and therefore what occaÅ¿ion had we to be angry with Doctor Clench?

div.p: Then the Report was perus'd by the Lord Chief JuÅ¿tice, and return'd to him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. HarriÅ¿on, this will do you no good, not being to the preÅ¿ent purpoÅ¿e, therefore proceed in your defence.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, I have Å¿ome WitneÅ¿Å¿es to prove where I was at the time that the Coachman Å¿ays the Murther was done. Cryer, call Thomas Turner a Porter, and Mr. Maccaffee.

div.p: Who appeared, but were not Sworn, and were Examined apart, at the RequeÅ¿t of Mr. Darnell, the Kings and Queens Councell.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p:
My Lord, I Å¿hall prove by theÅ¿e WitneÅ¿Å¿es, that I was elÅ¿ewhere when the Coach-man Å¿aid he took up thoÅ¿e two Men, a little after
Nine-a-Clock. Pray Mr. Turner, give an Account to the Court, what time it was, I called you to carry my Trunk.

sp.speaker: Tho. Turner.
sp.p: My Lord, I was, about Seven of the Clock in the Evening, the 4th Day of January laÅ¿t, at the Two Kings and Key in Fleet-Å¿treet, over againÅ¿t Salisbury-Court; and I was told, that a Gentleman at Joe's Coffee-houÅ¿e in Salisbury-Court wanted a Porter; and I preÅ¿ently went to him thither, and it was this Mr. HarriÅ¿on: and he bad me take up his Trunk, which I did, and carried it to the Two Kings and Key, and he went with me: And he asked me to get Å¿ome Linnen waÅ¿h'd for him againÅ¿t the next Day at Noon; and he gave me Å¿ome Linnen, which I carried to my Wife to waÅ¿h for him, and return'd to him again preÅ¿ently; and I went with him from thence, and carry'd his Trunk to his Lodgings in Paul's Church-yard; and when I had deliver'd his Trunk, I left him there; and then it was about Eight of the Clock at Night.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: At whoÅ¿e HouÅ¿e was it, you deliver'd the Trunk?

sp.speaker: Tho. Turner.
sp.p: My Lord, it was at Mr. Jones's HouÅ¿e, in Paul's Churchyard.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And did he Å¿tay within?

sp.speaker: Tho. Turner.
sp.p: No, my Lord, he went out preÅ¿ently after me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you any where elÅ¿e with him that Night, beÅ¿ides at the places you have mentioned?

sp.speaker: Tho. Turner.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: My Lord, I will prove that Mr. HumÅ¿ton miÅ¿takes an Hour.

sp.speaker: Mr. HumÅ¿ton.
sp.p: I cannot miÅ¿take an Hour, becauÅ¿e the Shop is Å¿hut up about Nine-a-Clock, and it was Å¿hut when you came firÅ¿t to my Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: My Lord, there Å¿tands in Court one Thomas JohnÅ¿on, Apprentice to Mr. Pemmel; he can tell what time a-night it was I came to Mr. HumÅ¿ton's, he let me in; I deÅ¿ire he may be call'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Swear Thomas JohnÅ¿on.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What time of the Night was it that Mr. HarriÅ¿on came to Å¿peak with Mr. HumÅ¿ton, on that Night Dr. Clenche was murder'd?

sp.speaker: Tho. JohnÅ¿on.
sp.p: My Lord, on the 4th of January laÅ¿t at Night, Mr. HarriÅ¿on came to my MaÅ¿ter's HouÅ¿e, and knock'd at the Door; and I went to the Door, and open'd it, for I had Å¿hut up the Shop; and he ask'd me if Mr. HumÅ¿ton was within? And I told him, he was: And he came in, and went up to Mr. HumÅ¿ton's Chamber; and it was then about Nine of the Clock, as near as I can gueÅ¿s.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where is your MaÅ¿ter's HouÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Tho. JohnÅ¿on.
sp.p: My Lord, it is the Golden Key in Fleet-Å¿treet, over againÅ¿t Fetter-lane end.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Pray call Adam Maccaffee, Mr. White, Mr. Carden, and John Allen.

div.p: [Who appear'd. And Mr. Maccaffee Å¿tood up.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Maccaffee.
sp.p: Upon Monday the 4th Day of January laÅ¿t, the PriÅ¿oner was at my HouÅ¿e, and Å¿tay'd from Nine a-Clock, till paÅ¿t Eleven, and play'd at Cards with one Mr. Baker, and one Mr. White and his Wife; and he Å¿tay'd till it had Å¿truck Eleven-a-Clock.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where is your HouÅ¿e, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Maccaffee.
sp.p: My HouÅ¿e is in Chancery-Lane, over againÅ¿t Serjeants-Inn.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he tell you where he had been before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Maccaffee.
sp.p: He Å¿aid, that he had been towards the City, and was very cold.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he Å¿ay any thing of Mr. HumÅ¿ton?

sp.speaker: Mr. Maccaffee.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Pray, What Room were you in? Did you play at Cards in the Kitchen?

sp.speaker: Mr. Maccaffee.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnel.
sp.p: Were they up Stairs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Maccaffee.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor.
sp.p: At what time a-night did they come in?

sp.speaker: Mr. Maccaffee.
sp.p: Betwixt Nine and Ten-a-Clock, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What made you take notice of the Day of the Month, and Hour of the Day?

sp.speaker: Mr. Maccaffee.
sp.p: My Lord, I heard that Dr. Clenche was murder'd, and that Mr. HarriÅ¿on was taxed with it, and that made me take notice of the Day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Call Mrs. Maccaffee.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: MiÅ¿treÅ¿s, What time did Mr. HarriÅ¿on come to your HouÅ¿e on the 4th of January laÅ¿t at Night?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Maccaffee.
sp.p: My Lord, it was as near Nine-a-Clock as any thing can be, when he came in firÅ¿t.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long did he Å¿tay there?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Maccaffee.
sp.p: I cannot tell how long he Å¿tay'd, but there were two Accidents happen'd; one was, our Playing at Cards; and the other was, that there was a Pick-pocket carried by to be pump'd at Lincolns-Inn; it was from Nine to Eleven before he went away, and there were Mrs. White, Mr. Baker, and one Mrs. FaireleÅ¿Å¿e.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did any one come with the PriÅ¿oner, to your HouÅ¿e? In what humour did he Å¿eem to be?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Maccaffee.
sp.p: No, my Lord, there was no one came with him, and he never Å¿tirr'd out, neither did he Å¿eem to be diÅ¿order'd; he was neither too merry, nor too melancholy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where did he Å¿ay he had been?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Maccaffee.
sp.p: He Å¿aid, that he had been in the City.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he uÅ¿e to frequent your HouÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Maccaffee.
sp.p: Formerly he did; but I had not Å¿een him in half a Year before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: How many were there, do you Å¿ay?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Maccaffee.
sp.p: There was one Mrs. FaireleÅ¿Å¿e, and one Mrs. White, and my Å¿elf, and my Husband was upon the Bed, and Mr. White came for his Wife about Ten-a-Clock, to come home.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Do you remember that Mr. Baker was there?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Maccaffee.
sp.p: Yes, he was there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray MiÅ¿treÅ¿s, did Mr. HarriÅ¿on come in, and find them at Cards?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Maccaffee.
sp.p: No, we went to Cards, afterwards.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was your Husband?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Maccaffee.
sp.p: He was upon the Bed in the Kitchen.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Call Mr. Baker.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: This Gentleman, the PriÅ¿oner, is a Stranger to me; but here is a Letter that he Å¿ent me two or three Days afterwards. I came into Mrs. Maccaffee's HouÅ¿e about half an Hour after) Nine a-Clock, with two Women more: Mrs. Maccaffee owed me Money, and I had been in Lincolns-Inn, for I do Å¿ome Work there for Sir Thomas Cooke, and the Women ask'd me to play at Cards; and I Å¿aid, that I did not care to Play, becauÅ¿e I had been abroad, and could not get any Money, which made me out of humour. My Lord, I never Å¿aw the Man in my Life before.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who were they that play'd at Cards?

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: It was one Mrs. FaireleÅ¿Å¿e, the Woman of the HouÅ¿e, and Mr. HarriÅ¿on, and my Å¿elf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who were together?

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Mrs. FairleÅ¿s and I, and the Woman of the HouÅ¿e and Mr. HarriÅ¿on the PriÅ¿oner, and we play'd for a Penny a Corner, I cannot Å¿ay any more to it, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long did he Å¿tay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: I left him there after Ten a Clock, and as I hope for mercy, I never Å¿aw him but once before, and I had not known him again, but by a particular Token.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Were there not Å¿ome Accidents happen'd at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Yes, there came a Vintner's Boy to ask for a Woman, one Mrs. Frances, and he was in great haÅ¿te, and a Pick-pocket was carried up the Lane to be Pump'd at Lincolns-Inn Pump.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Call Mrs. FairleÅ¿Å¿e, call Mrs. Whipple.
Call Mr. Sutton,

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where do you live, and what is your Name?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sutton.
sp.p: My Lord, my Name is Sutton, and I live in Stone-cutter's-Å¿treet.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Mr. Sutton, what time was it that I was coming by, when one Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el and you were Drinking?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sutton.
sp.p: My Lord, it was about Eleven a Clock at Night, at the King's Head-Tavern at Chancery-Lane end.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: What had I on, a Cloak and a Muff?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sutton.
sp.p: Yes, I think you had a Cloak on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: What time was it, was it before or after Eleven a Clock?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sutton.
sp.p: It was about a quarter before Eleven.

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor.
sp.p: What day of the Month was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sutton.
sp.p: It was the fourth of January.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was he going, which way went he?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sutton.
sp.p: He was going towards Fleet-Bridge, my Lord, and I called after him, but could not make him hear me at firÅ¿t, but afterwards he came to us.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Pray call Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.

sp.speaker: Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.
sp.p: I can't hear, my Lord, but if you pleaÅ¿e to permit Mr. Sutton to Å¿peak to me, I can hear his Voice better than any Man's.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Speak as loud as you can, Sir, and we will let you hear us, Mr. Sutton muÅ¿t not Å¿peak for you.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Pray Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el what time of Night was it that you Å¿aw me go by you, when you were drinking at the Kings-Head-Tavern?

sp.speaker: Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.
sp.p: I can't tell, my Lord, I have not heard a Clock theÅ¿e three years.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where were you going at that time of Night?

sp.speaker: Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.
sp.p: I was going to Wild-Street, to the Chyrurgeon's-Arms, to Receive Å¿ome money.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came Mr. Sutton to go with you?

sp.speaker: Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.
sp.p: He had been with me all that day, and I deÅ¿ired him to go with me; and, my Lord, I did expect that the money would have been brought to me, but was not, Å¿o I went for it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, and what then?

sp.speaker: Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.
sp.p: While we Å¿taid at the King's-Head Tavern door to drink Wine, Mr. Sutton Å¿ent the Drawer to call Mr. HarriÅ¿on.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What had you been doing before that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.
sp.p: We had (I Å¿uppoÅ¿e) I been drinking together.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where had you been before you came to the King's-Head Tavern?

sp.speaker: Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.
sp.p: We had been at the HorÅ¿eÅ¿hoe-Tavern in Chancery-Lane.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you requeÅ¿t Mr. Sutton to go with you?

sp.speaker: Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.
sp.p: Yes, I did, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You Å¿ay your eaÅ¿ineÅ¿s was to go to Wild-Å¿treet, to receive Å¿ome money?

sp.speaker: Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.
sp.p: Yes, it was, my Lord, and I did receive it?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was it that you met Mr. HarriÅ¿on, the PriÅ¿oner?

sp.speaker: Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.
sp.p: My Lord, I can't poÅ¿itively Å¿ay, but by computation of the Night, I believe it was about Eleven a Clock.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you meet Mr. HarriÅ¿on before you went to the HorÅ¿eÅ¿hooe-Tavern, or after?

sp.speaker: Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.
sp.p: Afterwards, my Lord, I Å¿aw Mr. HarriÅ¿on turn at the Corner of Fleet-Å¿treet, towards Fleet-Bridge.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: At the time when Mr. Sutton and you went firÅ¿t out, did you agree of your going to the HorÅ¿eÅ¿hooe-Tavern?

sp.speaker: Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.
sp.p: We went thither to Å¿end for the Gentleman out of Wild-Street.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When you had been Drinking all the Afternoon, how came you to Å¿top your Coach at the King's-Head?

sp.speaker: Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.
sp.p: We Å¿topt there, whilÅ¿t Mr. Sutton Å¿ent for Å¿ome body to come to him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You Å¿aid juÅ¿t now that Mr. Sutton Å¿ent for Mr. HarriÅ¿on.

sp.speaker: Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I do not remember that, but Mr. Sutton Å¿aid Harry, or HarriÅ¿on, where art thou going, when he went by us.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: My Lord, this Man is a Å¿tranger to me. Call John Allen, Drawer at the King's-Head-Tavern.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: John Allen, what time of Night was it that Mr. Sutton and Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el came to your HouÅ¿e in a Coach?

sp.speaker: J. Allen.
sp.p: I believe it was about Eleven a Clock.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How much Wine had they?

sp.speaker: J. Allen.
sp.p: Two Half Pints of Canary.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Night was it? what Day of the Month was it?

sp.speaker: J. Allen.
sp.p: My Lord, I can't remember what Day of the Month, but it was that Night that Doctor Clench was murther'd.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you Å¿ee Mr. HarriÅ¿on there?

sp.speaker: J. Allen.
sp.p: I can't tell that, I never Å¿aw him, 'till I Å¿aw him in PriÅ¿on.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Did not you go to Mr. Maccaffee's HouÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: J. Allen.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Did not one Å¿trike you with a Muff?

sp.speaker: J. Allen.
sp.p: Yes, but I can't remember who it was.

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor.
sp.p: Look upon that Man, do you not know him to be the PerÅ¿on?

sp.speaker: J. Allen.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I do not know him to be the PerÅ¿on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Who Å¿ent you to Crown-Court?

sp.speaker: J. Allen.
sp.p: Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: J. Allen.
sp.p: For a Servant Maid, and he bid me tell her that he had a deÅ¿ire to Å¿peak with her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: How long did you tarry at the HouÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: J. Allen.
sp.p: I did not Å¿tay at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Call Mr. Carden, Drawer at the King's-Head Tavern.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: What time did Mr. Sutton come to your HouÅ¿e, did you Å¿ee any one Å¿tand at the Coach Å¿ide? and what Cloaths had he on?

sp.speaker: Carden.
sp.p: I Å¿aw one Å¿tand at the Coach Å¿ide, and he had a Hanging-Coat or a Cloak on, it was about the Hour of Eleven, to the beÅ¿t of my knowledge, and I Å¿aw a Man go into the Coach, and come out again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Coroner.
sp.p: What time of Night do you Å¿hut your Doors, eÅ¿pecially on Monday Nights; and were they Å¿hut when Mr. Sutton called in the Coach?

sp.speaker: Carden.
sp.p: We Å¿hut them commonly about Eleven a Clock at Night, but on Monday Nights uÅ¿ually later; they were Å¿hut when Mr. Sutton called, and I opened them for him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Can you Å¿ay that the PriÅ¿oner was the Man that drank with Mr. Sutton?

sp.speaker: Carden.
sp.p: To the beÅ¿t of my knowledge (looking on the PriÅ¿oner) that is the Man, I can't be poÅ¿itive, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, have you any more WitneÅ¿Å¿es?

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p:
No, my Lord, unleÅ¿s Mr. EÅ¿Å¿ington be here, he promiÅ¿ed to be here to give an account of me. My Lord, there is a Gentleman that
is in the PreÅ¿s-Yard, one Mr. _____
Butler, I deÅ¿ire lie may be Å¿ent for, if your LordÅ¿hip pleaÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Let him be fetch'd down.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But, in the mean time, it behoves you to give account of theÅ¿e things. FirÅ¿t, why did you Å¿ay that you were a Parliament Man? Secondly; why did you leave your Lodgings, and take other Lodgings in Paul's-Church-Yard? Thirdly, why did you Å¿ay that you had extraordinary buÅ¿ineÅ¿s? Give Å¿ome account what your buÅ¿ineÅ¿s was, and who that Gentleman was, that Å¿taid for you in the Street, when Mr. HumÅ¿tone deÅ¿ired you to Å¿tay and Sup with him, what hinder'd you from accepting his Invitation?
