Now we would have you to ConÅ¿ider of theÅ¿e things, and give an anÅ¿wer to them, for it much concerns you Å¿o to do.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: My Lord, firÅ¿t as to the firÅ¿t, I do declare that I never went for a Parliament Man, nor never Å¿aid Å¿o: Secondly, that Night I was to go out of Town, I had left word at Å¿everal CoÅ¿Å¿ee-HouÅ¿es that I was going out of Town upon earneÅ¿t BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s, and with above twenty People beÅ¿ides, that I was going out of Town, and I was about to go to BaÅ¿ing-Stoke, to a Gentleman that owed me Money, one Mr. Bulling, but I could not get money to go.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Prove that you were to go into the Country.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: My Lord, I can't prove that now, except I could have Å¿ent to BaÅ¿ing-Stoke.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That you Å¿hould have done before now; why did you not Å¿tay with Mr. HumÅ¿ton, when he Invited you to Sup with him? You might have been better entertained there, than by going among Å¿trangers to Play at Cards for a Penny a Corner, at an Ale-houÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: My Lord, I was unwilling to Å¿tay, becauÅ¿e he had Strangers with him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What if he had, you are not Å¿uch a baÅ¿hful man, that you could not Sup with Strangers.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: My Lord, Mr. Rowe was accuÅ¿ed with me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What if he was? he was under Å¿ome SuÅ¿picion, and he hath made it appear where he was at the time the Fact was Committed, and now he is DiÅ¿charged.

div.p: Then Mr. Butler was brought into Court from Newgate, attended by a Keeper.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Mr. Butler, Pray tell the Court what Mr. Fairbeard Å¿aid to you about me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Butler.
sp.p: My Lord, Mr. Fairbeard asked me what I could Å¿ay about what Mr. HarriÅ¿on had Å¿aid to me concerning the Murther of Doctor Clench? I told him I could not tell what to make of his broken and rambling Speeches and DiÅ¿courÅ¿es, they being moÅ¿t of them Å¿poken when he was in his Drink. This is all that I know, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: This is not a WitneÅ¿s for your turn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call Mrs. Anwell.

div.p: [Who was Å¿ent for from her Lodgings in Brownlow-Street in Holborn, and appeared, and was Sworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Madam, pray give an account what Mrs. AÅ¿hbolt told you concerning any Man's being in a Coach at Brownlow-Å¿treet end?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Anwell.
sp.p:
I know nothing of my own Knowledge, but the Night that Doctor Clench was Murthered, I Å¿ent Mrs. AÅ¿hbolt of an Errand, and at her return, I blam'd her for Å¿taying Å¿o long; and Å¿he told me, that as Å¿he was returning home, a Coach Å¿top'd at Brownlow-Street end, with two Men with
Cloaks on in it, and that one of them bad the Coachman go for Doctor Clench, and deÅ¿ire him to come to them, and in his going Å¿everal times look'd back as if he Å¿uÅ¿pected the men would leave the Coach, and Å¿o Å¿he Å¿tayed until Doctor Clench came and wont into the Coach, and that one of the men gave the Doctor his Place; and that one of them had a Fair Perriwig and a Sanguine Complexion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: What diÅ¿courÅ¿e had you with her when you heard that thoÅ¿e men had Murdered Doctor Clench?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Anwell.
sp.p: She told me that one of thoÅ¿e men had a Fair Perriwig and a Sanguin Complexion, and that one of them had a Cloak on.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did Å¿he Å¿ay that Å¿he obÅ¿ervod either of their Faces?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Anwell.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, Å¿he Å¿aid that one of them had a round Face, and a big Voice.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did Å¿he Å¿ay, Å¿he could know him again?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Anwell.
sp.p: No, my Lord, Å¿he did not Å¿ay Å¿o, but Å¿he Å¿aid that Å¿he could know his Voice again. And after the laÅ¿t SeÅ¿Å¿ions I told Mrs. Clench of it, and that if Å¿he would Å¿end for the Young Woman, Å¿he would inform her further of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Madam, Pray what was the reaÅ¿on, that Å¿he did not DiÅ¿cover it Å¿ooner to Mrs. Clench?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Anwell.
sp.p: Why truly becauÅ¿e Mrs. AÅ¿hbolt, her Mother, was unwilling Å¿he Å¿hould concern her Å¿elf in Å¿uch a Matter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Call another WitneÅ¿s, Mr. Jones, Coachmaker.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, take notice, that now Å¿he Å¿ays that thoÅ¿e Gentlmen had Cloaks on, that came in the Coach to Brownlow-Å¿treet end.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, we heard her what Å¿he Å¿aid.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: My Lord, I will ask this WitneÅ¿s, Mr. Jones, a QueÅ¿tion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Pray Sir, tell my Lord and the Jury, what Mrs. AÅ¿hbolt did at Newgate.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: My Lord, I went with her to Newgate, together with Doctor Clench his Coachman, and when Å¿he came to Newgate, before Å¿he Å¿aw Mr. HarriÅ¿on (only Å¿tood at the Chamber Door and hoard him Å¿peak) Å¿he Å¿aid, that, to the beÅ¿t of her thoughts, he was the man that put his Head out of the Coach to look after the Coachman, and Swore at him, for Å¿he knew his Voice. And when Å¿he came to Å¿ee him, Å¿he Å¿aid, that Å¿he knew his Face, and Declared that was the Man that put his Head out of the Coach.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he look out of the Coach, Mrs. AÅ¿hbolt?

sp.speaker: Mrs. AÅ¿hbolt.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he put his head out of the Coach, and look'd after the Coach-man, to Å¿ee if he went Right to Doctor Clench's Door, and did Å¿wear at him, becauÅ¿e he went no faÅ¿ter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How could you diÅ¿cern his Face?

sp.speaker: Mrs. AÅ¿hbolt.
sp.p: By the Light of two Lamps, that were near, which did Å¿hine into the Coach.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Can you take it upon your Oath that the PriÅ¿oner is the Å¿ame PerÅ¿on?

sp.speaker: Mrs. AÅ¿hbolt.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I can both by his Voice and Face.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, we Å¿hall Å¿hew your LordÅ¿hip Å¿omewhat in Relation to the Credit of thoÅ¿e WitneÅ¿Å¿es, that the PriÅ¿oner hath brought here; Particularly, as to Mr. Baker, we Å¿hall prove that he hath been Convicted for a Cheat. And as for Maccaffee, he keeps a very diÅ¿orderly HouÅ¿e, where ill People commonly reÅ¿ort.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: Cryer, Call Mrs. Martha WhelÅ¿tead, and Mr. Thomas Cole.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mrs. Jones, what time did Mr. HarriÅ¿on come to your HouÅ¿e, to his Lodging, that Night that the Murder was committed?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jones.
sp.p: I think it was about Eleven a Clock, or a little before Eleven.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What time on the Monday did he hire the Lodging of you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jones.
sp.p: It was Å¿ometime after Dinner.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It was before Night, was it not?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jones.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, it was before Night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: My Lord, I deÅ¿ire that Mr. Tanner may Read the Record againÅ¿t Mr. Baker, whereby it will appear that he was Indicted and Convicted at Hixes-hall, for Cheating the PariÅ¿h of St. Giles in MiddleÅ¿ex, when he was Scavenger there, by altering the Figures in the Book, and Rateing the Sums of Money Higher upon divers of the PariÅ¿hioners, than they were in the PariÅ¿h Book, and then Collecting and extorting the Money, Å¿o by him increaÅ¿ed, from them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tanner
sp.p: Reads the Indictment aforeÅ¿aid, by which it did appear to the Court, and to the Jury, that the Å¿aid Mr. Baker was Indicted for the Offence aforeÅ¿aid, and confeÅ¿Å¿ed the Indictment, and was fined for it twenty Shillings.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: My Lord, I was wrongfully Indicted, and TraverÅ¿ed the Indictment, and was acquitted.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Tanner, give me the Record.

div.p: Lord Chief JuÅ¿tice peruÅ¿es the Record.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: I have Read the material parts of the Record, and do find that you were Indicted for that offence, and that you confeÅ¿Å¿ed the Indictment, and were fined for it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: My Lord, I was acquitted of it, and can prove it by Captain Cannon, who knows me, and my Reputation, and he is in Court.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Baker, the Record teÅ¿tifieth the Truth, and cannot erre, therefore you have great Confidence to aver againÅ¿t it, yet I will hear what Captain Cannon Å¿aith.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Call Captain Cannon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Capatin Cannon, do you know this Mr. Baker?

sp.speaker: Captain Cannon.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, very well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnell.
sp.p: My Lord, I deÅ¿ire that Captain Cannon may be Å¿worn.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Tanner, Swear Captain Cannon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Sir, do you know that Mr. Baker was Indicted for falÅ¿ifying of the Scavengers Book when he was Scavenger, and Acquitted or Convicted, and what do you know about it?

sp.speaker: Captain Cannon.
sp.p: My Lord, I am an Inhabitant of the PariÅ¿h of St. Giles in the Fields, and Å¿o I was when Mr. Baker was Scavenger, and do well remember thas Å¿ome of the Inhabitants of that DiviÅ¿ion whereof he was Scavenger, were troubled, and complained, that they were charged more than uÅ¿ually they had been to the Scavengers Rate; and it was diÅ¿cover'd that Å¿everal Figures of the Book by which Mr. Baker Collected the Money to the Scavengers Rate, were blotted and altered, and did not agree with the PariÅ¿h Leadger-Book, but the Sums in his Book Å¿o blotted and altered were raiÅ¿ed; whereupon it was ordered that he Å¿hould be Indicted for it, and it was done accordingly, and he was Fined for it, and to the beÅ¿t of my Remembrance he confeÅ¿Å¿ed that Indictment.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Captain Cannon, Pray tell the Court and the Jury, of what Reputation Mr. Baker is now.

sp.speaker: Captain Cannon.
sp.p: My Lord, he is now of none of the cleareÅ¿t Reputations.
Captain James Partrich, of the Å¿ame PariÅ¿h, being in Court, offered himÅ¿elf, and gave the Å¿ame Account of Mr. Baker that Captain Cannon did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnel.
sp.p: Crier, Call Mr. Francis Brampton, Mrs. Martha WhelÅ¿tead, and Mr. Thomas Cole.

div.p: [And Mrs. WhelÅ¿tead and Mr. Cole appeared, and were Å¿worn.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnel.
sp.p: Mrs. WhelÅ¿tead, pray give the Court and Jury an Account what diÅ¿orderly HouÅ¿e Mr. Maccaffee keeps?

sp.speaker: Mrs. WhelÅ¿tead.
sp.p: My Lord, I dwell in Crown-Court in Chancery-Lane, over againÅ¿t Mr. Maccaffee's HouÅ¿e; and he and Å¿he are very ill People; and keep a very evil and Å¿candalous HouÅ¿e, and Å¿uch as are reputed to be HouÅ¿e-breakers, Pick-pockets, and Lewd-women, do uÅ¿e and frequent the HouÅ¿e; and there is commonly at late hours in the Night, PerÅ¿ons calling out Murder, and Whore and Rogue, and Å¿uch Å¿ort of Language, diÅ¿turbing their Neighbours; and their HouÅ¿e hath been Å¿everal times Å¿earched by Å¿everal ConÅ¿tables for Å¿tollen Goods, and for the PerÅ¿ons that have Å¿tolen them; and upon Å¿uch Searches, there have been Å¿tolen Goods found there: And I have Å¿een great LewdneÅ¿s there between Men and Women; and the Neighbours do account it a HouÅ¿e of an ill Fame, and do avoid going thither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tho. Cole.
sp.p: My Lord, I do know Mr. Maccaffee and his Wife; I do dwell over againÅ¿t his HouÅ¿e, and they are reputed to keep an ill HouÅ¿e, and moÅ¿t PerÅ¿ons that frequent it, are reputed to be PerÅ¿ons of lewd and evil Lives and ConverÅ¿ations; and it is amongÅ¿t the Neighbourhood noted for a Å¿candalous HouÅ¿e, and Å¿everal ConÅ¿tables have Å¿everal times Å¿earched there for Å¿tolen Goods.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What have you more to Å¿ay Mr. HarriÅ¿on?

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: I cannot Å¿ay any thing more; you may deal with me according to my DeÅ¿erts in this Matter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You may aÅ¿Å¿ure your Å¿elf, that we will do you no wrong; Have you any more to Å¿ay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnel.
sp.p: My Lord, We have another WitneÅ¿s come now, who was not here before. Crier, Call Mr. Charles Whitfield.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnel.
sp.p: My Lord, This Gentleman can give your LordÅ¿hip an Account what the PriÅ¿oner Å¿aid of his being juÅ¿t come out of the Country, upon the fifth of January laÅ¿t. Pray tell my Lord what you know, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cha. Whitfield.
sp.p:
My Lord, Upon the fifth day of January laÅ¿t, being the Day after Dr. Clench was murdered, I went to Joe's Coffee-HouÅ¿e in Salisbury-Court, and there Mr. HarriÅ¿on Å¿itting by the FireÅ¿ide, Å¿ays I to Mr. HarriÅ¿on, Where have you been for a long time that I have not Å¿een you? Says he, I have been in the Country: Where Å¿ays I? Says he, about twenty Miles off, in Kent; and I want a LandreÅ¿s, and a Lodging. Says I, do you hear the News, Sir? What News, Å¿ays he? Why, Å¿aid I, of Dr. Clench's being murdered: I cannot tell the OccaÅ¿ion, Å¿aid I, but he was found dead in a Coach laÅ¿t Night in Leadenhall-Å¿treet. Then Å¿ays he, I did love him very well once, but of late he hath been a barbarous Rogue to a Gentlewoman, a Friend of mine, and Å¿he is in the Compter now: And Mr. HarriÅ¿on Å¿aid it was a juÅ¿t Judgment of God upon the Doctor for being Å¿o great a Villain to the Gentlewoman; therefore I will write to her
preÅ¿ently, and give her an Account of his Death. And, my Lord, the Contents of his Letter were theÅ¿e, as near as I can remember.

body.p: I Am juÅ¿t now going to Lambeth, but hearing of Dr. Clench's Murder, I do hereby give you an Account of it, and can impute it to no leÅ¿s than a juÅ¿t Judgment of God upon him for his BaÅ¿eneÅ¿s Å¿hewed to you. And if you think fit to Å¿end to Madam Clench, it may be Å¿he may Å¿end Å¿omewhat towards your Relief, Å¿he now being a Widow as well as you.

closer.signed: Madam, I am yours to command, Henry HarriÅ¿on.

sp.p: My Lord, after this came into the Å¿ame Coffee-HouÅ¿e another PerÅ¿on, one Mr. RavenÅ¿croft, of whom Mr. HarriÅ¿on asked Å¿ome QueÅ¿tion about Dr. Clench; who reply'd, That he heard that Dr. Clench was murdered, and that it was committed by a Bully of the Town that belonged to a Gentlewoman in the Compter who was laid in there upon Dr. Clench's account; at which, he was much Å¿tartled: Says he again. There is no PerÅ¿on familiar with that Gentlewoman but my Å¿elf; for I know, and am concerned in all her Affairs: Perhaps then I may be taken up about it: Or, my Lord, he uÅ¿ed Words to that effect.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: My Lord, this Woman was not in the Compter upon Dr. Clench's account.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, the WitneÅ¿s don't Å¿ay Å¿o; but that it was the DiÅ¿courÅ¿e of the Town that Å¿he was, and the Town did Å¿uppoÅ¿e her Å¿o to be. What did he Å¿ay further, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Whitfield.
sp.p: My Lord, he Å¿aid that he had been in Kent about twenty Miles off; and he Å¿aid, that he wanted a LandreÅ¿s, becauÅ¿e he had Å¿ome foul Linnen to waÅ¿h; which he produced. This was on the TueÅ¿day, and the Murder was committed on the Monday-night before: And, my Lord, there were two more Gentlemen that heard him as well as I, that he Å¿aid, That he had been about twenty Miles off in Kent, and that he was newly come to Town. Now, my Lord, I could not imagine for what ReaÅ¿on this Man Å¿hould Å¿ay, that he had been out of Town about a Fort-night or three Weeks, when he was in that HouÅ¿e but the Monday-night before; that is, the Night the Murder was committed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnel.
sp.p: Crier, call Mr. BiÅ¿hop.

sp.speaker: Mr. BiÅ¿hop.
sp.p: About three Years ago the PriÅ¿oner came to my MaÅ¿ter's Shop to cheapen Å¿ome Linnen, and whenâ

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Hold, what are you doing now? Are you going to arraign his whole Life? Away, away, that ought not to be; that is nothing to the Matter. Have you done, PriÅ¿oner?

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I have done, I refer my CauÅ¿e to your LordÅ¿hip.

div.p: Then the Court Å¿ummed up the Evidence very particularly to the Gentlemen of the Jury, as followeth;

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Gentlemen of the Jury; The PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, Henry HarriÅ¿on, Å¿tands indicted for the wilful Murder of Dr. Andrew Clenche, who was barbarouÅ¿ly murdered on the fourth day of January laÅ¿t: You have heard the WitneÅ¿Å¿es that have been Å¿worn; and upon their TeÅ¿timony, it doth appear that two PerÅ¿ons came to Brownlow-Å¿treet-End in a Coach after nine a Clock at night, and Å¿ent the Coach-man to the Doctor's HouÅ¿e, under pretence to get him to a Patient, a Friend of theirs, that was Å¿ick. By this Contrivance, they got him into their Coach, which they had brought for that purpoÅ¿e, and then they ordered the Coach-man to drive to Leadenhall-Å¿treet; and when they came about Holborn-Bars, one of them ask'd the Coach-man why he drove Å¿o Å¿low, and bad him drive faÅ¿ter. When they came to Leadenhall-Å¿treet, then they bad him drive to the Pye-Tavern without Aldgate; where one of them bad the Coach-man ask for one Hunt; but he not being there, one of them bad the Coach-man return back, and gave Å¿ix Pence to the Watch to come through the Gate, which was Å¿hut in the mean time; and when they came to Leadenhall-Market, one of them gave the Coach-man three Shillings and Å¿ix Pence, and Å¿ent him to buy a couple of Fowls; which the Coach-man did buy, and brought them to the Coach; but when he came back, he found the Doctor in the body of the Coach leaning againÅ¿t the fore Seat of the Coach, a Handkerchief being tied about his Neck with a Coal in it, placed upon his Wind-pipe; which Hankerchief and Coal have been produced in Court.

The QueÅ¿tion is, Gentlemen, Whether the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar be Guilty of this baÅ¿e and barbarous Murder? To prove which, there have been a very long Evidence given, Å¿ome PoÅ¿itive, Å¿ome CircumÅ¿tantial. It has been proved that Dr. Clenche had Å¿ome Dealings with a Woman named Vanwicke, and had lent her one hundred and twenty Pounds, and had taken a Mortage for it. This PriÅ¿oner, Mr. HarriÅ¿on, was a great Acquaintance, and very intimate with this Woman; and did concern himÅ¿elf in the management of her Affairs: and becauÅ¿e Dr. Clenche did refuÅ¿e to lend the Woman more Money, therefore he had an AnimoÅ¿ity againÅ¿t Dr. Clenche. The Money not being paid to the Doctor as he did expect, he did call it in; and therefore this Gentlewoman did oftentimes repair to Dr. Clenche to deÅ¿ire farther Time, or Forbearance, becauÅ¿e Å¿he could not raiÅ¿e or procure the Money elÅ¿ewhere. That about MichaelmaÅ¿s laÅ¿t it Å¿eems Å¿he came to a Coffee-houÅ¿e near Warwick-houÅ¿e in Holborn, and there was Mr. HarriÅ¿on; where they conÅ¿ulted what to do. And it was agreed, that the MiÅ¿treÅ¿s of the HouÅ¿e and Mrs. Vanwicke Å¿hould go to Dr. Clench's; but Mr. HarriÅ¿on Å¿hould Å¿tay behind, for it was not thought convenient that he Å¿hould go, leÅ¿t he Å¿hould provoke the Doctor. When they came to the Doctor, Mrs. Vanwicke was very importunate to have Å¿ome more Money; but the Doctor would lend her no more. And when they returned to the Coffee-houÅ¿e again, Mr. HarriÅ¿on enquired what paÅ¿Å¿ed between the Doctor and Mrs. Vanwicke. She told him, that the Doctor would not furniÅ¿h her with any more Money, although Å¿he had preÅ¿Å¿ed him to do it, and urged her great NeceÅ¿Å¿ities, but adviÅ¿ed her to go to Service. Damn him, Å¿ays HarriÅ¿on,
does he Å¿ay that a Woman of your Quality Å¿hould go to Service? He is a great Rogue, and deÅ¿erves to have his Throat cut; but let me alone, I will manage him.

At another place there was a DiÅ¿courÅ¿e betwixt Mr. HarriÅ¿on and one Mr. JohnÅ¿on; and that the PriÅ¿oner did then Å¿peak very hard and ill Words of Dr. Clenche: And that Mr. HarriÅ¿on came frequently to him; and one time laid his hand upon his Sword, uÅ¿ing Å¿ome menacing Words, but what they were he cannot tell: But he likewiÅ¿e Å¿ays, that at Å¿everal times he did expoÅ¿tulate with him, and told him, That he would not do any good with Å¿uch DiÅ¿courÅ¿es as theÅ¿e are, &c. That the Mortgage-Money not being paid, it was thought fit, That there Å¿hould be a ProÅ¿ecution made to get poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the mortgaged EÅ¿tate, and that the Tenants Å¿hould be forbid to pay their Rents. And Mr. HarriÅ¿on went to Mrs. WeÅ¿t the Tenant, Å¿ome few days before St. Thomas day laÅ¿t, and demanded the Rent of her. To which Å¿he made anÅ¿wer, That Dr. Clenche had forbid the paiment of the Rent to Mrs. Vanwicke. Thereupon Mr. HarriÅ¿on grew very angry, and anÅ¿wered, That Dr. Clench was a Rogue and a Villain, and bid her that Å¿he Å¿hould not pay him any Rent. And the WitneÅ¿s Å¿aith further, That the Doctor being preÅ¿t to let her have Å¿ome more Money, refuÅ¿ed to do it, becauÅ¿e Å¿he would Å¿pend it all upon HarriÅ¿on.

Then the CounÅ¿el for the King called Å¿ome WitneÅ¿Å¿es, who gave you account of the PriÅ¿oner's Å¿hifting his Lodgings the day before the Murder was done. He takes a Lodging at Mr. Garway's in Thread-needle-Å¿treet, on the twenty third day of December, and there he continued till about the firÅ¿t of January. The Å¿econd of January he was at Garway's Shop; and on the Sunday night he came and fetcht away his Things. The Monday after, being the day that this barbarous Fact was committed, he Å¿ent a Letter to Mrs. Garway, to acquaint her that he was gone out of Town; but he left three half Crowns with her Maid to pay for his Lodging. But as to his going out of Town, it was falÅ¿e, for he never went into the Country, but took a Lodging at Mr. Jones's in Paul's Church-yard. It's obÅ¿ervable alÅ¿o, that he went for a Parliament-Manâª when he lodged at Mr. Garway's, and had his Footman to attend upon him, &c. There it was that he was Å¿ â¢â¢â¢ to have an ordinary Handkerchief, and to hold it to the Fire; which was taken notice of by Mrs. JackÅ¿on, the Daughter of Mrs. Garway, which was not Å¿utable, as Å¿he thought, to a Parliament-Man's Quality, but rather fit for a Seaman, for it was like the Apron of the Maid in the HouÅ¿e: which hath been Å¿hewed in Court, and compared with the Handkerchief that was tied about Dr. Clench's Neck. She Å¿aith it is the Å¿ame, or very like that which Å¿he did Å¿ee Mr. HarriÅ¿on hold in his hand.

Cartwright the Officer at the Compter, he tells you, that the Sunday night, the day before the Murder, Mr. HarriÅ¿on came to WoodÅ¿treet-Compter, and enquired for Mrs. Vanwicke, and that he only was in her Chamber, and no other Body on that Å¿ide of the HouÅ¿e but Mrs. Vanwicke, the PriÅ¿oner, and this Cartwright the Keeper, who Å¿tood at the Door, and heard HarriÅ¿on Å¿ay, That he would have the Blood of that Rogue, and named Clench, or Winch.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: My Lord, he was not in the Room.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, he was not; but there were none on that Å¿ide the HouÅ¿e but You, Cartwright, and Mrs. Vanwicke.

Now, on the Monday on which this Fact was committed, he having taken a Lodging at Jones his HouÅ¿e, he came thither with a Porter, who brought his Portmantua-Trunk about eight a Clock at night; and after he had been there a little while, he went away.

And you are told, by a Gentleman that lodges at the Golden-Key againÅ¿t Fetter-lane end; That he had Å¿ome Acquaintance with the PriÅ¿oner, that he had lent him a Morning-Gown; and that about nine a Clock that very night, he came to his Lodging in a Cloak; and then the Gentleman asked him for his Gown; and he told him, that he had brought it with him. Thereupon the Gentleman invites Mr. HarriÅ¿on to Å¿tay and Å¿up with him. Mr. HarriÅ¿on Å¿aid, he could not Å¿tay, for he was engaged; he muÅ¿t be gone, for that a Gentleman Å¿taid in the Street for him to go about extraordinary BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s.

The Coachman tells you, That near about that time two Men in Fleet-Å¿treet, near Fetter-lane end, hired his Coach of him to go to Brownlow-Å¿treet to Dr. Clench's; but he can't poÅ¿itively Å¿ay, that the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar was one of them, but he Å¿wears, he does verily believe that he was one of them.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: He Å¿aid before your LordÅ¿hip, That he could not remember what I had on.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, well, he doth not remember it now; but being hired to go to Dr. Clench's, he drove to the Street end and no further, becauÅ¿e the Gate at the lower end was Å¿hut up, and he could not turn his Coach in the Street; but he was Å¿ent by them to the Doctor's, to deÅ¿ire the Doctor to come out to them, and they Å¿at in the Coach in the mean time. The Doctor made haÅ¿te, and went to them immediately, and they drove away to Leaden-hall, and then to Aldgate; and they called at the Py-Tavern, and enquired for one Mr. Hunt a Chirurgeon, as I mentioned to you before: He not being there, they returned to drive through Aldgate, gave the Watch Å¿ix-pence, and paÅ¿Å¿ed through the Gate without any manner of notice taken: but if the Watch had done their Duty, it might have been better diÅ¿covered. But further, the Coachman tells you, that when he came to Leaden-hall Street, they called to him, and directed him to buy one Fowl; and after that he had been gone a little way from the Coach, they called him back, and bad him take Å¿ome more Money and buy two Fowls. So he went and bought the Fowls; but when he came back, the two Gentlemen were gone, and he found the Doctor Å¿till in the Coach; and he not Å¿tirring, he thought he had been in Drink: but upon further examination, and calling the Watchman with his Candle, it appeared that the Doctor was Å¿trangled with a Handkerchief and a Coal.

There is one Mrs. Elianor AÅ¿hbolt, who lives in Brownlow-Å¿treet with her Mother, and had been Å¿ent of an Errand; and between nine and ten of the Clock at Night, Å¿he Å¿aw the Coachman in Brownlow-Å¿treet, and thought that thoÅ¿e Men in the Coach might put a Trick upon him, by going away without paying him his Fare. And Å¿he Å¿ays further, That by the help of the Lamps Å¿he did diÅ¿cern the Face of this HarriÅ¿on in the Coach; he had a Cloak on, with a light Perriwig, and looked out of the Coach, and did Å¿wear at the Coachman; and by this means Å¿he knew him when Å¿he Å¿aw him again, to be the Å¿ame Man, both by his Face and Voice. This Woman indeed was not before
the Coroner, and Å¿he gives you this reaÅ¿on for it, becauÅ¿e her Mother was not willing Å¿he Å¿hould be concerned in Å¿uch a matter as this was; and what Å¿he could Å¿ay, was not known to Mrs. Clenche until after the Å¿econd SeÅ¿Å¿ions: And when he was in Newgate, Å¿he Å¿aw him there, and declared he was the Å¿ame Man.

There was another piece of Evidence, viz. That of the Boy's, who does not appear, he was examined before the Coroner. There has been Evidence given of ill practice to take him out of the way, and therefore his Affidavit is read for Evidence: He Å¿wears he Å¿aw two Gentlemen come out of the Coach when it Å¿tood in Leaden hall Å¿treet, and that having Å¿een the PriÅ¿oner in Newgate Å¿ince, doth believe him to be one. This, Gentlemen, is the Sum and SubÅ¿tance of the Evidence for the King, to prove that the PriÅ¿oner was one of thoÅ¿e that committed the Murder.

You have heard likewiÅ¿e what the PriÅ¿oner Å¿ays for himÅ¿elf; he does undertake to prove that he was in another Place, (that is) that he Å¿hould come into Maccafee's HouÅ¿e in Crown-Court over againÅ¿t Serjeants-Inn in Chancery-lane: and Maccafee, he tells you, that there were Å¿ome other Company there, and that HarriÅ¿on came in very cold, and that they went to Cards, and plaid for one Penny a Corner at Whisk; and that he did continue there from nine till eleven a Clock; and if he was there then, it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible he Å¿hould be guilty of this Fact, for the Fact was done between the Å¿ame Hours.
Maccafee's Wife tells you the Å¿ame, and they both tell you who were there beÅ¿ides, and who plaid together, and are poÅ¿itive that the PriÅ¿oner was there.

Baker Å¿ays, That he went away about half an hour after ten at Night, and left HarriÅ¿on behind him. To confirm this Evidence, they have called two other WitneÅ¿Å¿es beÅ¿ides the Drawers at the King's-Head Tavern, viz. Mr. Sutton the Surgeon, who lives in Stone-cutters Street, and Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿el: Mr. Sutton Å¿ays, they had been at the HorÅ¿eÅ¿hoe Tavern in Chancery-lane, and called for half a Pint of Sack at the King's-head Tavern when they came by: and as they Å¿at in the Coach, Mr. HarriÅ¿on came by accidentally, and one of them looking out of the Coach, cries Harry, or HarriÅ¿on; and he went to them, and they drank together another half Pint of Sack.

As to their meeting with HarriÅ¿on, and as to other PaÅ¿Å¿ages there, RuÅ¿Å¿ell Å¿ays the Å¿ame; but as to the time of Night he is not poÅ¿itive. And they Å¿ent one of the Drawers to a HouÅ¿e in Crown-Court to enquire for Å¿ome Body there.

The Drawers of the King's-Head Tavern, Å¿ay, That Mr. Sutton and Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿ell did call there about that time; and that they drank two half Pints of Wine: and that when they were drinking, a Man came by with a Hanging-Coat or Cloak on, and drank with them. And one of the Drawers went to call Å¿ome Body in Crown-Court; and one of the Company up with his Muff and gave him a Å¿lap in the Face.

Now this is the Sum and SubÅ¿tance of the Evidence that you have heard on the behalf of the PriÅ¿oner, to induce you to believe that he was not the PerÅ¿on that was concerned in the Murder of Doctor Clenche.
To which Evidence an AnÅ¿wer hath been offered;
FirÅ¿t, As to thoÅ¿e WitneÅ¿Å¿es, Maccafee and his Wife, divers WitneÅ¿Å¿es have been produced to prove, that they are People of doubtful Credit; it Å¿eems they keep an HouÅ¿e of ill Fame.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: I am glad, my Lord, that I was there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, well, Gentlemen, the People of the HouÅ¿e are not of very good Reputation, they keep a naughty and a diÅ¿orderly HouÅ¿e, (if you believe the WitneÅ¿Å¿es) you may conÅ¿ider of their Credit.

And as to Mr. Baker; About nine Years Å¿ince he was convicted of an arrant Cheat, which is no leÅ¿s than Forgery, for altering the Scavenger's Rate for St. Giles's PariÅ¿h, and therefore the leÅ¿s Credit is to be given to his Evidence; for now it appears that he is a Knave upon Record: and the very Record it Å¿elf was produced againÅ¿t him, which is true without doubt, notwithÅ¿tanding his pretence of Innocency. What is Å¿aid by Mr. RuÅ¿Å¿ell and Mr. Sutton, I muÅ¿t leave to your conÅ¿ideration; they had been a drinking, and the Drawer Å¿ays they were at the King's-Head Tavern at 11 of the Clock at Night. Mr. HarriÅ¿on the next day after the Murder, met a Gentleman at Joes Coffee-HouÅ¿e in Salisbury-Court; and though he had taken a Lodging in Paul's Church-Yard, yet he Å¿aid that he was newly come to Town, and had been in Kent, and had remained there about three Weeks; and that he wanted a LaundreÅ¿s and a Lodging, although he had not been out of Town, and had taken a Lodging but the day before: And then he told the WitneÅ¿s who diÅ¿courÅ¿ed with him about the Death of Dr. Clenche, That he had formerly loved him, but he Å¿aid he had been of late a barbarous Rogue to a poor Gentlewoman a Friend of his; and that the juÅ¿t Judgment of God had fallen upon him for Å¿o doing, and that he would write to her to give her an account of it; and adviÅ¿e her to write to Mrs. Clenche, and to tell her that Å¿he was a Widow now as well as Mrs. Vanwick; and he thought by that Means to move Mrs. Clenche to pity her, being a Widow as well as her Å¿elf: And that whilÅ¿t they were talking thus, one Mr. RavenÅ¿croft tells him, that Dr. Clenche was murdered, and that a Bully of the Town, that belonged to a Gentlewoman in the Compter, one Mrs. Vanwick, was Å¿uÅ¿pected. At which Mr. HarriÅ¿on was much Å¿tartled, and Å¿aid, That no one was concerned with that Gentlewoman but himÅ¿elf; and for ought he knew, he might be taken up for it. This is that which he Å¿aid.

Now what Å¿aid Mr. HarriÅ¿on farther for himÅ¿elf? Why, Å¿ays he, this Gentlewoman is not in PriÅ¿on at the ProÅ¿ecution of Dr. Clenche, and was not Å¿o affirmed, but Å¿o reported; and whether it were Å¿o or no is no great matter. Gentlemen, you ought to conÅ¿ider of the Evidence that you have heard againÅ¿t him, and alÅ¿o to weigh well the Evidence he hath brought for himÅ¿elf.

It is moÅ¿t plain, if you believe the WitneÅ¿Å¿es, that Mr. HarriÅ¿on was concerned for this Woman Vanwick, and hath threatned Dr. Clenche, called him Rogue and RaÅ¿cal, and Å¿aid, that he deÅ¿erved to have his Throat cut; that HarriÅ¿on went under a DiÅ¿guiÅ¿e for Å¿ome time before the Murder. You have had an Account of the Handkerchief, what kind of Handkerchief HarriÅ¿on had, and what Handkerchief was
taken about Dr. Clench's Neck, you have Å¿een: And you heard what Evidence was given by Mr. HumÅ¿tond; how the PriÅ¿oner was with him about nine a Clock that Night; and how he refuÅ¿ed to Å¿tay and Å¿up with Mr. HumÅ¿tond. If Mr. HarriÅ¿on had no earneÅ¿t buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, one would have thought he might have Å¿taid with Mr. HumÅ¿tond better than to have gone to an Ale-HouÅ¿e in Crown-Court, and plaid at Cards at one Penny a piece a Corner; he might have had better Fare no doubt.

The WitneÅ¿Å¿es for the PriÅ¿oner Å¿ay for him, That he came to Maccafee's HouÅ¿e about 9 a Clock at night, and Å¿taid till eleven: That is contrary to that Evidence given for the King, viz. That he was in the Coach at Brownlow-Å¿treet End; for if he was at Maccafee's HouÅ¿e all the time they mention, it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible he Å¿hould be guilty. All thoÅ¿e things are under your Å¿erious ConÅ¿ideration. You had beÅ¿t go together, and if you are not Å¿atisfied upon the Evidence you have heard, that he is guilty, then you ought to acquit him; but if you are Å¿atisfied that he did commit this Murder, then you ought to find him guilty.

Then the Jury withdrew, and the Court adjourned for half an hour; and when they were returned, the Jury came to give their Verdict; and being called over, anÅ¿wered to their Names; and Mr. HarriÅ¿on was brought to the Bar.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arraign.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Are you all agreed of your Verdict?

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: âYes.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arraign.
sp.p: Who Å¿hall Å¿ay for you?

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: âOur Foreman.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arraign.
sp.p: Henry HarriÅ¿on, Hold up thy Hand.
Look upon the PriÅ¿oner; How Å¿ay you? Is he guilty of the Felony and Murder whereof he Å¿tands indicted, or not guilty?

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Guilty of wilful Murder.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arraign.
sp.p: What Goods or Chattels? &c.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: None that we know of.

sp.speaker: Major RichardÅ¿on.
sp.p: Look to him, he is found guilty of wilful Murder.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arraign.
sp.p: Then hearken to your Verdict as the Court hath recorded it.

You Å¿ay that Henry HarriÅ¿on is guilty of the Felony and Murder whereof he Å¿tands indicted, but that he had no Lands, nor Tenements, Goods nor Chattels, at the time of the Felony and Murder committed, nor at any time Å¿ince to your Knowledg: And Å¿o you Å¿ay all?

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: âYes.
Then the PriÅ¿oner was remanded to Newgate until the laÅ¿t Day of the SeÅ¿Å¿ions, and then he was brought to the Bar to receive Sentence of Death.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arraign.
sp.p: Henry HarriÅ¿on, Hold up thy Hand.

Henry HarriÅ¿on, You Å¿tand convicted of Felony and Murder, for the Murder of Dr. Andrew Clenche: What can you Å¿ay for your Å¿elf why Judgment Å¿hould not be given againÅ¿t you, to die according to Law?

sp.speaker: Mr. D. Recorder.
sp.p: Mr HarriÅ¿on, You have been Indicted, Arraign'd and Convicted of Felony and Murder, for the Murder of Dr Andrew Clenche. You have had a long, and a fair and favourable Tryal, as any PerÅ¿on that ever have been Tryed at this Bar.

The Jury that has paÅ¿Å¿ed upon your Life and Death hath Convicted you, and the Court are now ready to do their laÅ¿t Act, which is to pronounce that Sentence that the Law does inflict upon Å¿uch Crimes as you Å¿tand Convicted of.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: I expect no Mercy here, therefore I humbly deÅ¿ire you would interceed to the Queen, that I may have twelve Days allowed me, in order to my better Preparation for Death.

sp.speaker: Mr. D. Recorder.
sp.p: âWell.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: I muÅ¿t needs acknowledg, that I was Tryed before the beÅ¿t of Judges, my Lord-Chief-JuÅ¿tice Holt, but one thing I think Å¿trange, that my WitneÅ¿Å¿es Å¿hould be examin'd Å¿ingly, and not the King's.

sp.speaker: Mr. D. Recorder.
sp.p: That is no more than what is uÅ¿ual, the CounÅ¿el for the King and Queen requeÅ¿ted it, and you did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: I begg'd that I might have timely notice of my Tryal, and I had not; there were Å¿even People in my Company at the time when this black and bloody Murder was done, and I could not get them to be here.

sp.speaker: Mr. D. Recorder.
sp.p: You have had a long time to get them ready, and you preÅ¿Å¿ed on your own Tryal, which you Å¿hould not have done if you had not been ready.

sp.speaker: Mr. HarriÅ¿on.
sp.p: I humbly Å¿ubmit.

div.p: Then the uÅ¿ual Sentence of Death was pronounc'd againÅ¿t him, and he was Remanded to Newgate.

div.head: The Examination of Henry HarriÅ¿on this 6th. Day of January, 1691.
div.p:
THIS Examinant being ask'd where his Lodgings are, anÅ¿wereth, That he Lodgeth at the Golden-Ball in Paul's Church-Yard, and came to Lodge there on Monday Night about Eleven of the Clock or half an hour after, but took the Lodgings in the Morning, the MaÅ¿ter of the HouÅ¿e being one Mr. Jones a Cane-Chair-Seller; and before that time this Examinant lodged at the Hand and Apple near the Exchange, which Å¿aid Lodging he left on Saturday laÅ¿t in the Morning, and paid for them on Sunday Afternoon. And this Examinant Å¿aith, That on Saturday Night laÅ¿t he lodg'd at the White Belcony in Old Southampton-Buildings, the MiÅ¿treÅ¿s of the HouÅ¿e being one MiÅ¿treÅ¿s Pitts: And this Examinant Lodged there on Sunday Night alÅ¿o. And this Examinant Å¿aith, That he was at
the King's Head in Crown-Court in Chancery-Lane upon Monday laÅ¿t, from between Seven and Eight of the Clock at Night, and Å¿tayed there until Eleven, playing at Cards with the Man and Woman of the HouÅ¿e, and other PerÅ¿ons unknown. And being ask'd where he Dined on Monday, and how he Å¿pent his Time on Monday in the Afternoon, he Å¿aith, he cannot give any Account. And this Examinant Å¿aith, that on TueÅ¿day laÅ¿t Mr Hartly of Old Southampton-Buildings, diÅ¿courÅ¿ing concerning the Murder of Doctor Clench, Å¿aid, That this Examinant was Å¿uÅ¿pected to be Guilty of that Murder. And this Examinant further Å¿aith, That he wore the Å¿ame Clothes, he hath now on upon Monday laÅ¿t, and hath worn them a great while having no other Clothes to wear.
THE TRYAL OF John COLE, FOR THE MURTHER OF Dr. Andrew Clenche, 1692.
LONDON, Printed by Thomas Braddyll, and are to be Sold by William Battersby at Thavies Inn-Gate, and R. Baldwin near the Oxford Arms in Warwick-lane. MDC XCII.

div.head: THE Arraignment, Tryal, and Acquittal OF JOHN COLE FOR THE MURTHER OF Dr. Andrew Clenche.

opener.dateline: At the SeÅ¿Å¿ions of Gaol-Delivery of Newgate, holden for the City of London, at JuÅ¿tice-Hall in the Old Baily, on the 31Å¿t. day of AuguÅ¿t, and on the 1Å¿t. and 2d. days of September, in the 4th. year of their MajeÅ¿ties Reign.

div.p: THE Keeper of Newgate did, according to Order of the Court being Å¿ate, on Friday the 2d. day of September, bring up the body of John Cole to the SeÅ¿Å¿ions PouÅ¿e in the Old-Baily, London; who being at the Bar, was Arraigned upon an Indictment of Felony and Murther, found againÅ¿t him by the Grand-Jury of the City of London, for the Murther of Dr. Andrew Clenche.

sp.speaker: Clerk of Arraignment.
sp.p: JOhn Cole, hold up thy Hand.
You Å¿tand Indicted by the Name of John Cole, of London, Labourer, for the Murther of Dr. Andrew Clenche, &c. and the Indictment is in Å¿uch manner as that againÅ¿t Mr. Henry HarriÅ¿on.
How Å¿ay you, John Cole, are you Guilty of the Felony and Murther whereof you Å¿tand Indicted, or not Guilty?

sp.speaker: Joen Cole.
sp.p: Not Guilty.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: CulpriÅ¿t, How will you be Tryed?

sp.speaker: John Cole.
sp.p: By God and my Country.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: God Å¿end you a good Deliverance.

div.p: And afterwards the Å¿aid John Cole was brought to the Bar upon his Tryalâª and thoÅ¿e PerÅ¿ons who were returned upon the Jury, were called over twice, and their Appearances recorded.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: You, John Coleâª TheÅ¿e Men that you Å¿hall hear call'd, and perÅ¿onally do appear, are to paÅ¿s between our Sovereign Lord and Lady the King and Queen, and you upon Tryal of your Life and Death; if therefore you will challenge them, or any of them, your time is to challenge them as they come to the Book to be Sworn, and before they be Sworn.

div.p:
Then the Jury were call'd and Sworn, and th â¢ n were counted; and the Twelve Sworn were theÅ¿e whoÅ¿e names followâª
JÆ²RORS.
John Clay
Edward Sherlock
John Ruddyer
Cuthbert Lee
Thomas WatÅ¿on
Thomas Milburne
Ben. Evens
George BeÅ¿tow
Archibauld WilÅ¿on
Thomas Applebury
Nicholas Harris
Ralph Cates
Sworn.

p.hi: Then Proclamation was made for Information and Evidence as uÅ¿ual.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: John Cole, Hold up thy Hand.

Gentlemen, You that are Sworn, look upon the PriÅ¿oner, and hearken to his CauÅ¿e. He Å¿tands Indicted by the Name of John Cole, late of London, Labourer, &c. as in the Indictement. Upon this Indictment he hath been Arraigned, and thereunto hath pleaded not Guilty; and for his Tryal hath put himÅ¿elf upon God and his Country which Country you are. Your Charge is to enquire whether he be Guilty of this Felony and Murther whereof he Å¿tands Indicted, or not Guilty. If you find that he is Guilty, you are to enquire what Goods or Chattels, Lands or Tenements he had at the time of the Felony and Murther Committed, or at any time Å¿ince.

If you find him not Guilty, you are to enquire whether he f â¢ ed for it; if you find that he fled for it, you are to enquire of his Goods andâª Chattles as if you found him Guilty, if you find him not Guilty, nor that he did fly for it, you are to Å¿ay Å¿o, and no more; and hear your Evidence.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: Cryer, Call Mary Milward, JoÅ¿eph Dueley, John Dueley, Jane Warren, Sarah Dueley, Anne Gann, Anne GeÅ¿Å¿on, Anne Warren, Elizabeth Harper, Mary Edwards, John Gamble, John Sykes, Robert Robone, Richard Eades, Richard Marryott, Samuel Reve â¢ , Henry Milward, Squire Dalley, William Brown, Francis Hobbs. Who were all Sworn.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: Set Mary Milward up.

sp.speaker: Mr. JuÅ¿tice Dolben.
sp.p: What have you to Å¿ay, Woman, againÅ¿t Cole the PriÅ¿oner, concerning the Murther of Dr. Clenche?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: My Lord, my Husband declar'd to me, that he and Mr. Cole were in the Coach with Dr. Clenche, and that they two kill'd Dr. Clenche.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Thats no Evidence at all what your Husband told you; that won't be good Evidence if you don't know Å¿omewhat of your own knowledge.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: My Lord, I have a great deal more that my Husband told me, to declare.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: That won't do: what if your Husband had told you that I kill'd Dr. Clenche, what then? That will Å¿tand for no Evidence in Law: We ought by the Law to have no Man call'd in queÅ¿tion, but upon very good Grounds and good Evidence, upon Oath, and that upon the Verdict of twelve good Men. Have you any body that can prove any thing againÅ¿t Cole, or does it all ariÅ¿e barely from your Husband's Report?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: My Husband declared that he and Mr. Cole were to go under a pretence to Rob the Doctor, and Å¿o to take their Opportunity to kill him; and the firÅ¿t time they call'd at Doctor Clenche's, he was not within, but the Å¿econd time they went he was within, and then they did the Murther.

sp.speaker: Mr. JuÅ¿tice Powel.
sp.p: When dy'd your Husband MiÅ¿triÅ¿s?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: The 23d. of May laÅ¿t, Sir,

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Here hath been two or three SeÅ¿Å¿ions Å¿ince that time, why did not you take up Cole about it before now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: I did not know where to find him.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Why, then you Å¿hould have gone to a MagiÅ¿trate, and told him of it, and have taken Å¿ome advice about it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: I did aÅ¿Å¿oon as I had found Mr. Cole.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Your buÅ¿ineÅ¿s had been to have diÅ¿cover'd this to Mrs. Clenche, and Å¿he Å¿hould have look'd after Cole; is Mrs. Clenche here?

sp.speaker: Sir Will. AÅ¿hurÅ¿t.
sp.p: Here is her Brother-in-Law,

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Do you proÅ¿ecute Cole upon this Indictment

sp.speaker: Mr. WiÅ¿e.
sp.p:
No my Lord, I do not, Mrs. Milward is the ProÅ¿ecutor, and Å¿he charged Mr. Cole with the Murther of my Brother Dr. Clenche; and Å¿he told my SiÅ¿ter Clenche, that Mr. Milward her Husband confeÅ¿Å¿ed and Å¿aid Å¿ometime before his Death, that he and Mr. Cole Murther'd Dr. Clenche in a Coach; and Mrs. Milward Å¿aidâª That Å¿he had Å¿ufficient Evidence againÅ¿t Mr. Cole for it, and my SiÅ¿ter Clenche told Mrs. Milward that Mr. HarriÅ¿on Murther'd Dr. Clenche in a Coach, together with another PerÅ¿on, which my SiÅ¿ter Clenche Å¿aid, Å¿he believed was the Å¿aid Mr. Milward, Husband of the Å¿aid Mrs. Milward; and that Å¿he had a Warrant againÅ¿t him, the Å¿aid Mr. Milward, upon SuÅ¿picion for it, but could not take him, and that Å¿he Å¿uÅ¿pected that there were other PerÅ¿ons contrivers or concerned in it; who were Å¿et down at the Blue-Boar's Head Ale-HouÅ¿e near Clements-Inn, by Mr. Gamble a Coach-man out of his Coach, together with the Å¿aid
Mr. Milward in their return from Dr. Clenche's HouÅ¿e that Night he was Murder'd; and, my Lord, by my SiÅ¿ter Clenche's Order, I went with Mrs. Milward to all her WitneÅ¿Å¿es, and took Notes of their Evidence, and I went with Å¿everal of them to my Lord Chief JuÅ¿tice Holt's Chamber, before whom they gave in their Informations upon Oath about it, and when I had done it, I told Mrs. Milward I could find no Evidence that Å¿he had againÅ¿t Mr. Cole, more than that he was at Dr. Clenche's HouÅ¿e, and at the Å¿aid Blue-Boar's-head Ale-houÅ¿e with Mr. Milward, and another PerÅ¿on, that Night Dr. Clenche was Murdred, and Å¿o he might be concern'd in the contrivance of it; whereupon Mrs. Milward was diÅ¿Å¿atisfied, and Å¿aid, Å¿he was not able to ProÅ¿ecute him for it; Å¿o my SiÅ¿ter Å¿aid to Mrs. Milward, that Å¿he might if Å¿he would preferr an Indictment againÅ¿t him for it, and that Å¿he would pay for it, and other Charges about it, which Å¿he did; and Mrs. Milward hath a Note of the Names of all her WitneÅ¿Å¿es, and may call them.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Clayton,
sp.p: Did not you lie at Cole's HouÅ¿e, MiÅ¿treÅ¿s?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Why did not you take him then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: BecauÅ¿e he abÅ¿conded himÅ¿elf, and gave out that he was gone to Sea.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Was there no quarrel betwixt Cole and you about your Goods?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I had no quarrel with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: BecauÅ¿e you did not do it Å¿ooner, have you not been troubled with your Husbands GhoÅ¿t? Tell the Jury the Å¿tory: we have heard on't, but I am afraid they will Laugh at you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: That was very true, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Well if you have any thing elÅ¿e to Å¿ay, that is Material, Speak, otherwiÅ¿e my Brother and I are of opinion, that what you have already offer'd is no Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: My Lord, here is a Coach-man or two, that can acquaint your LordÅ¿hip of the Matter of Fact, better than I can.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: Cryer, call John Gamble the Coach-man

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: You, Coach-man, do you know the PriÅ¿oner?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gamble.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I do not know him.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Look upon him, do you know him or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gamble.
sp.p: No truly, my Lord, I do not know him.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Why! Look you, Woman, he does not know him; you Coachman, the Å¿tory is well know, therefore I ask you again upon your Oath, if that PriÅ¿oner at the Bar be one of the three PerÅ¿ons, that you carried to the Blue Boar's Head on the back-Å¿ide of St. Clements, that Night Dr. Clenche was Murder'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gamble.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, I cannot be poÅ¿itive whether he be one of them or no. I took up in Cheap-Å¿ide three Men into my Coach, and Å¿et one of them down at Grays Inn, and drove the other two to Dr. Clenche's HouÅ¿e that Night he was Murder'd, and he was not at home, and afterwards the Man I had Å¿et down, came in again, and I Å¿et them all down at the Blue-Boar's-Head Ale-houÅ¿e near Clement's Inn Gate, about Eight a Clock at Night.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Arr
sp.p: Set up W. Brown Servant at the Blue Bear's-Head.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Hark you, is this one of the three Men that the Coach Man Å¿et down at your MaÅ¿ter's HouÅ¿e that Night Dr. Clenche was Murder'd.

sp.speaker: Will. Brown.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, it is.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: What time did they come to your HouÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: Will. Brown.
sp.p: They came about Eight a Clock at Night, and this Man and the other Å¿tayed till after a Eleven a Clock; only Milward went out and returned preÅ¿ently, and then immediately he went out again, which was before Nine a Clock, and return'd not until Eleven a Clock or after.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: What time was Dr. Clenche Kill'd?

sp.speaker: Will. Brown.
sp.p: About Ten a Clock, or betwixt Ten and Eleven as I think.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Who went out firÅ¿t, only Milward?

sp.speaker: Will. Brown.
sp.p: Only Mr. Milward, my Lord, but this Man Å¿tayed all the time, till Eleven a Clock at Night, and another who went by the Name of Harper, as I am Å¿ince informed.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Why then this Man could not be in the Coach when Dr. Clenche was Murdred, Å¿o HarriÅ¿on and Milward Kill'd the Doctor in all probability, for he Å¿ays, this Man at the Bar, and another, Å¿tay'd at his MaÅ¿ters HouÅ¿e till after Eleven a Clock.

sp.speaker: Will. Brown.
sp.p: My Lord, when Milward came back he brought a Couple of Men with him in Soldiers Habit about Eleven of the Clock at Night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: My Husband told me, that Mr. Cole and he went out of the HouÅ¿e, and left Mr. Harper behind.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: But this Man Swears, that the PriÅ¿oner did not go out of the HouÅ¿e till Eleven a Clock at Night, and they were Å¿et down about Eight of the Clock, and Dr. Clenche was found Kill'd a little after Ten at Night, and that Milward went out, and then came in again about Eleven a Clock, and brought two men with him; 'tis to be fear'd he had been Killing Dr. Clenche in that time; have you any more to Å¿ay, if this man Å¿ays true, nothing can be Å¿aid more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: Speak what was done, when they came to drink the â¢ ot of Ale, Mr. Brown.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: I would fain know, MiÅ¿treÅ¿s, who Å¿et you on upon this buÅ¿ineÅ¿s? Is there not Å¿ome Money promis'd you? It was not the fear of your Husband's GhoÅ¿t that put you upon it, I am afraid.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: I am much wronged, my Lord, I know nothing of any Money offer'd me.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: What Å¿ay you more?

sp.speaker: Will. Brown.
sp.p:
My Lord, Mr. Milward being at my MaÅ¿ter's HouÅ¿e that Night Dr. Clenche was Kill'd, deÅ¿ired me to make a Fire in the Å¿ame Room the next morning, and that he would come again then; and I made a Fire accordingly, but he came not then, nor afterwards at any time to my knowledge, but on a Sunday Night about a Fortnight after came the Two PerÅ¿ons, that came with Mr. Milward in the Coach to my MaÅ¿ters HouÅ¿e that Night Dr. Clenche was Murdred, and my MaÅ¿ter being above Å¿tairs, I Å¿ent him word, that the Two
men were there who were there that Night that the Doctor was Murdred, and they Inquired for Mr. Milward, Å¿aying, he promiÅ¿ed to meet them there, and he not being there, before my MaÅ¿ter could come down, they paid for the Pot of Drink and went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: When they came together to the Blue-Boar's-head they had Å¿ome evil deÅ¿ign, no doubt, but if it be true that thoÅ¿e Two men Å¿taid from Eight a Clock till Eleven, then it could not be this Man that Murder'd Dr. Clenche; but hark ye, Fellow, you Å¿ay, there were Three PerÅ¿ons, whereof Cole was one, and Milward the other, who was the Third?

sp.speaker: Will. Brown.
sp.p: I do not know his Name, my Lord, otherwiÅ¿e than as I have Å¿ince heard.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: The other Man's Name was Harper.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: You know nothing but what your Husband told you, and 'tis moÅ¿t probable that HarriÅ¿on and he did the Murder, for that it appears that the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar is not the Man that Kill'd the Doctor, that's plain. Have you any more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: About a Fortnight after the Murder was done, they came to inquire for my Husband at the Blue Boar's-head, and whilÅ¿t the TapÅ¿ter went to tell his MaÅ¿ter, they left their Money for the Drink and went away, and would not be Å¿een.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: What if they had run away, what then? If they were at the Blue-Boar when Dr. Clenche was Kill'd, they could not Kill him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: His MaÅ¿ter Å¿ays, that they were in the HouÅ¿e, and out of the HouÅ¿e, very often, call Mr. Dalley the MaÅ¿ter. Who appear'd and Å¿tood up.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dalley.
sp.p: My Lord, Two of them were not out of the HouÅ¿e all the Night, I am not poÅ¿itive that this is the Man that came in with Milward, but thoÅ¿e Two Men that came in with him, never went out at all until after Eleven a Clock at Night, but only Milward went out between Eight and Nine, and returned about Eleven a Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: What do you Å¿ay to this, Woman? your Husband told you that the PriÅ¿oner was one of the Two, this WitneÅ¿s cannot Å¿ay he was one, but Å¿ays poÅ¿itively thoÅ¿e Two men never went out till Eleven a Clock, and from St. Clements Danes to Leaden-hall-Å¿treet is not to go in and out, they muÅ¿t take a great deal of time to go thither and back again. Hark you, Mr. Dalley, you Å¿ay that thoÅ¿e Two men that Milward left, never went out of your HouÅ¿e till after Eleven a Clock, you are Å¿ure on't.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dalley.
sp.p: No, my Lord, they did not go out.

sp.speaker: Mr. WiÅ¿e.
sp.p: Mrs. Milward hath Two WitneÅ¿Å¿es that can tell Å¿omewhat more of the matter, concerning her Husband's being concern'd in the Murder.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: My Husband told me, that the Coach-man took them up not far from Chancery-Lane end, and that Mr. Cole laid hands upon the Dr. in the middle of Holbourn.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: Cryer, Call John Sykes the Coach-man; who Å¿tood up.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sykes.
sp.p: My Lord, I took up Two men in Fleet-Å¿treet, about Fetter-Lane end.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: What manner of men were they? What Cloths had they on?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sykes.
sp.p: My Lord, one of them had a Light Coloured Periwig on, and the other was in Sad Colour'd Cloths, and Lank Hair, but I cannot be poÅ¿itive that this is one of them: They Asked me if I knew Dr. Clenche of Brownlow-Å¿treet? I told them, that I did not know the Dr. but I knew the Street: and they bid me Drive thither; and when I came to the Street's end, they Å¿ent me to the Doctor's HouÅ¿e, and bid me tell him, that Two Gentlemen were at the Street's end in a Coach, who deÅ¿ired him to go with them to one that was not well, Å¿o the Doctor came preÅ¿ently after me, and when he was in the Coach, they bid me Drive to Leaden-hall Å¿treet, and when I came about Holbourn-Bars they bid me Drive faÅ¿ter, and when I came to Leaden-hall-market, they bid me Drive to Algate, and I drove through the Gate to the Pye-Tavern, and when I had turned my Coach, they bid me Ask for one Hant a Chyrurgeon, but he was not there; and then I told them the Gate was Å¿hut, and one of them put his Hand out of the Coach and gave the Watch-man Six Pence to open the Gate, and then I drove back again to Leaden-hall-market, and there they bid me Å¿top again, and one of them gave me Half a Crown to Buy a Fowl, and I went a little way from the Coach, and one of them call'd me back again, and gave me a Shilling more, and bid me bring a Couple, and he bid me Ask for one Hunt a Poulterer; I went all over the Market, but I could find no Å¿uch man, Å¿o at length I bought the Fowls of another man, and would have had the man gone with me to my Coach, but he would not; then I came to my Coach Å¿ide, and found the Door open, and I found the Doctor Å¿itting at the bottom of the Coach with his Head againÅ¿t the CuÅ¿hion, and the Two men gone, and one of them Å¿eemed to be in drink when I took them up, and I thought him to be that man fallen aÅ¿leep, and that the Doctor and the Å¿ober man were gone to the PerÅ¿on that was not well, Å¿o then I call'd the Watch, and found the Doctor dead, and then it was about half an Hour after Ten a Clock at Night.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Then I Ask you, was that one of the men?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sykes.
sp.p: I cannot Å¿ay it, my Lord, I don't know him.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: What time of Night was it that you took them up at Fetter Lane end?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sykes.
sp.p: It was about Nine a Clock, Å¿omewhat after.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Why then, they Å¿ay, that this man never Å¿tir'd out of the HouÅ¿e from Eight a Clock till Eleven, this man can't be concern'd.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Ar.
sp.p: Set up John Dudley, which was done.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: Mr. Dudley, What did my Husband Å¿ay, concerning the Doctor, to you in the Country?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dudley.
sp.p:
He came into the Country preÅ¿ently after the death of the Doctor, and he Å¿ent for me, and was very much concerned, I Ask'd him what was the matter with him, and he told me, that he
was come out of Town about the Murder of Dr. Clenche; I told him, that I hoped that he was no ways concerned in it; he told me, No, but there was a Warrant out againÅ¿t him upon account that he Quarrell'd with the Coach-man that Night that he carried him to Dr. Clenche's; and he Å¿aid, that Mr. HarriÅ¿on had Å¿ent to him from Newgate, and told him, that he would give him Twenty Pounds, if he could make his Tryal eaÅ¿ie.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: MiÅ¿treÅ¿s, this makes it out, that he told you one Story, and to this WitneÅ¿s another, which contradicts your Story fully; he told him, that he came away for fear, and that he was Innocent of the Murder; and Å¿ince that he told you, that he was Guilty. Well, what elÅ¿e did he Å¿ay to you, Mr. Dudley.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dudley.
sp.p: He was much concerned to enquire after the Gazettes, and Letters, if he were in them, about the Doctor's Murder, and to enquire if Mr. Cole and Mr. Harper were taken up about it.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: You hear what is Å¿aid againÅ¿t you; what do you Å¿ay to it Mr. Cole?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cole.
sp.p: My Lord, I know nothing of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: No, I doubt you do, you were one of the Three that was Å¿et down on the back Å¿ide of St. Clement's Church, at the Blue-Boar's-head, where all things were ConÅ¿ulted.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cole.
sp.p: My Lord, there was not one word Å¿poke about the Killing of Dr. Clenche in my Company.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Were not you Acquainted with Milward.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cole.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Were you not with HarriÅ¿on?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cole.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I never Å¿aw him with my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Well, have you any more to Å¿ay?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: Call Mr. Hobbs, who Å¿tood up.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobbs.
sp.p: I met Mr. Milward in York-Buildings, and he Asked me how I did, and he went from me a little way, and then came to me again, and Ask'd me if I would drink, So we went to the George in York-Buildings and there we drank a Pot or Two; and he Ask'd me if I heard that he was AccuÅ¿ed about the Murder of Dr. Clenche; I told him, No, but he never told me any thing of this Man at the Barr.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: What was Milward?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobbs.
sp.p: I do not know how he got his Living.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Have you any Body elÅ¿e, MiÅ¿treÅ¿s?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Milward.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I know no more.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Gentlemen of the Jury, Cole the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar Å¿tands Indicted for Murthering Dr. Clenche, who, as it now appears, was Murther'd in a Coach by two PerÅ¿ons that were therein together with the Doctor. The queÅ¿tion now before you is, whether Cole was one of theÅ¿e two?

Gamble, the Coachman, Å¿wears, That the Night Doctor Clenche was killed, he took up Three Men in CheapÅ¿ide, Å¿et one of them down at Gray's-Inn, and drove on to Doctor Clenche's HouÅ¿e, the Doctor was not at home, then the third Man came in again to the Coach, and he drove to the Blew-Boar's-Head an AlehouÅ¿e by Clement's-Inn, and Å¿et thoÅ¿e Three Men down there, and 'twas then about Eight of the Clock.

Sykes the Coachman, Å¿wears, he took up Two Men at Fetterlane End in FleetÅ¿treet, and by their directions drove to BrownlowÅ¿treet, where the Doctor lived, whom they got into the Coach, and he drove as far as Aldgate, and through the Gate, and then came back to Leaden-Hall, was Å¿ent by the Two Men in the Coach to buy a Fowl, when he returned they were gone, but the Doctor found Dead in the Coach; and 'twas now half an hour paÅ¿t Ten.
The QueÅ¿tion now, as I Å¿aid before, is whether Cole the PriÅ¿oner at the Bar, was one of theÅ¿e two men.
The Woman tells you, Milward her Husband told her, that he and Cole were in the Coach with Doctor Clenche, and that they Two Kill'd Doctor Clenche.
She likewiÅ¿e tells you, her Husband told her, that Cole and her Husband went out from the Blew-Boars-Head near Clement's Inn, and left only Harper behind.

The Court hath already declar'd to you, that her Evidence, being only what her Husband told her, is no Evidence in Law to take away a Man's Life, eÅ¿pecially when it is Å¿ingle without any CircumÅ¿tance to confirm it, as here 'tis. But that is not all, there is a very great Evidence, that what Å¿he Å¿ays her Husband told her, is falÅ¿e.
He told her, Å¿he Å¿ays, that he and Cole went from the Blew-Boars-Head and Kill'd the Doctor, leaving only Harper behind.

The MaÅ¿ter of the HouÅ¿e and his Servant (WitneÅ¿Å¿es which Å¿he produceth) both Å¿wear, That her Husband went out alone, and leÅ¿t Two Men behind, who both Å¿taid in the HouÅ¿e till Milward return'd, which was about Eleven of the Clock. The MaÅ¿ter, 'tis true, cannot Å¿ay that Cole is one of the two, but the Servant is very poÅ¿itive he is, and both are PoÅ¿itive, that the two Men, that Milward left-behind, continued in the HouÅ¿e till Milward returned
at Eleven of the Clock. TheÅ¿e Two Mens DepoÅ¿itions do plainly contradict her Story, and if they Å¿wear true, Cole the PriÅ¿oner was not one of the PerÅ¿ons that Kill'd the Doctor.

You have all heard, I am Å¿ure, that one HarriÅ¿on hath been Convicted by a Jury in this Place for the Murther of Doctor Clenche: If he was one of the two, then Milward by his own ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion (if his Wife Å¿wear true) was the other; but this you cannot take notice of, the Record is not produced, neither hath the PriÅ¿oner taken notice of it, the QueÅ¿tion is only whether Cole be Guilty of the Murther? which I leave to you upon the Evidence you have heard.

div.p: The Jury having conÅ¿ider'd their Verdict, returned, That the PriÅ¿oner was not Guilty.
